PROCTEXT.PARA: FIRST SESSION OF THE THIRTY-SECOND PARLIAMENT
Pursuant to the Resolution of the Senate passed on 26 November 1981, the Senate met on Tuesday, 16 February 1982, at 3 p.m.
The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 3 p.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KILGARIFF

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 39 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate, in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are gravely concerned at proposed future hydro-electric developments in South West Tasmania. As this area is on the Register of the National Estate it is therefore of national concern and your petitioners humbly call upon the Senate to conduct a Senate Inquiry into South West Tasmania. A Federal Inquiry has been recommended by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly call upon the Federal Parliament not to allocate funds or allow funds to be raised for development of roads or dams in the South West of Tasmania but rather to provide such funds as would enable the preservation of this area. This is a national issue and therefore Tasmanians should not be made to bear any financial burden resulting from its preservation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RYAN

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 32 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
(a) that the Australian Government signed the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women in Copenhagen in 1980;
(b) that the Convention came into force on 3 September 1981;

(c) that Australian women suffer serious disadvantage in employment, education, accommodation, membership of licensed clubs, provision of goods and services including services relating to banking, insurance and the provision of grants, loans, credit or finance;

(d) that this disadvantage could be overcome by (i) making unlawful certain discrimination on the grounds of sex and marital status, (ii) eliminating discrimination on the grounds of sex and marital status and (iii) promoting affirmative action for women in employment.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Parliament pass the Sex and Marital Status Discrimination Bill 1981.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HEARN

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 17 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That all members of the Women's Services 1939-45 War qualify as 'Australian Soldier' under the Defence Service Homes Act for loans because on voluntarily joining the Australian forces they took the oath to resist His Majesty's enemies making themselves available for combat duty in War Zones, and according to Acts and Regulations of the period the Military women had enlisted for service anywhere, some Naval women to sail in any waters, with all servicewomen available for service in Papua New Guinea.

As those members of the Royal Australian Navy, the Australian Imperial Force and the Royal Australian Air Force of 1939-45 War who were not sent to War Zones are granted loans, refusal to grant eligibility to all Ex-servicewomen of 1939- 45 War is unjust and unfair.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you amend the Defence Service Homes Act by repealing Sub-section 4 (2A) (b) (c) (d) of the Principal Act as amended by No. 137 of 1978, and grant eligibility to all members of the Women's Royal Australian Naval Service, the Australian Women's Army Service, the Women's Auxiliary Australian Air Force, the Australian Army Medical Women's Service, and the Voluntary Aid Detachment of 1939-45 War.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MULVIHILL

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 20 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That Australian families will be seriously affected by the budget announcements which include raising of, or imposition of, Sales Tax on many items which must be provided by parents for their children's schooling.
We condemn the proposals as a regressive tax measure which will seriously affect Australia's students.

Sales Tax increases will affect the price to parents of a variety of items including school clothing, school footwear, exercise books, books and magazines for reading, stationery, sports equipment, and other school requisites and will seriously disadvantage parents who are already finding it difficult to provide essential educational items.
Your petitioners request that the Senate will reject outright any further imposition of Sales Tax on items which are essential to the educational progress of students.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RYAN

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 30 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament in Canberra assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:
That since 1788 discrimination has existed in Australia on particular grounds including, inter alia, grounds of sex, race, ethnic origin, marital status, pregnancy and/or sexual preference;

That since 1788 such discrimination has been accepted and promoted by Australian laws and practices, particularly in the provision of work, in appointment to jobs, in promotion to positions of authority and lucrative incomes, in the provision of goods and services, in the provision of accommodation and generally in relation to political, economic and social institutions of power.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That adequate and appropriate laws be immediately formulated and passed through the Parliament to render unlawful discrimination in all areas over which the Commonwealth holds power, namely, in employment of all persons in the Commonwealth Public Service and employed in Commonwealth Statutory Authorities and other bodies, in the provision of accommodation and the provision of goods and services under Commonwealth jurisdiction and also in all areas over which legislation for the Australian Capital Territory would be valid.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MULVIHILL

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the following petition, which is not in conformity with the Standing Orders, from 123 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned Australian citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Australian Government instruct the Film Australia to make a number of civil defence films, to be shown in National Network ABC for the education of the general public.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

That the petition be received.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROBERTSON; ROBERTSON

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the following petitions, which are not in conformity with the Standing Orders, from 110 and 82 citizens of Australia, respectively:

SPEECH.PARA: CIVIL DEFENCE ORGANISATIONS

To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned Australian citizens respectfully showeth: That the Australian Government give more money and equipment to the State Emergency Services Civil Defence Organisations. Equal to a $1 per head of population.
COUNTER DISASTER COLLEGE

To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned Australian citizens respectfully showeth: That the Commandant of Counter Disaster College at Mount Macedon, Victoria be instructed to:
(1) Give more priority to civil defence preparation courses.
(2) Install a closed TV circuit to every student's room, that more civil defence films be viewed by the students in the College.

That the petitions be received.

PETITION.TITLE: Institute of Early Childhood Development
PETITION.PARA: The humble petition of citizens of Victoria showeth that at a general meeting concern was expressed as to the necessity to retain the Institute of Early Childhood Development as an autonomous institution.

Your petitioners therefore pray that you would make note of the following resolution passed at a public meeting held in Melbourne on 12 August 1981: 'We request that the Federal Government continue funding the Institute of Early Childhood Development as an autonomous specialist institution recognising that it is unique in its capacity to serve the needs of the early childhood field in Victoria and throughout Australia.'
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Dame Margaret Guilfoyle (from 33 citizens), Hamer (from 11 citizens) and Jessop (from 25 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that the Sales Tax Amendment Bill which adds Sales Tax to presently exempted goods is a further financial burden on lone parents and low income families.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should ensure that the Government withdraws the Sales Tax Amendment Bill as it is highly inflationary and is a breach of Government promise given in Parliament by the Treasurer on 12 March 1981 that there would be no increase in indirect taxation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Service Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That the Ex-servicemen's and Women's Pension Association is a body formed for the express purpose of obtaining a Service Pension for all Ex-Service Personnel at sixty years of age for men and fifty-five years of age for women regardless of where they served during the 1939-45 war.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled , should give urgent consideration to a favourable decision to the granting of the Service Pension to all Ex-Service Personnel who served their country in time of need and who did not serve overseas through no fault of their own. The Service Pension is presently only granted to Re- turned Ex-Service Personnel.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: CARRICK; CHANEY; GUILFOYLE; JESSOP; MESSNER; PRIMMER; WITHERS
PETITION.TITLE: Tasmanian Wilderness Areas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate, in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at proposed hydro-electric developments in South-West Tasmania. As this area is on the Register of the National Estate it is of national concern and your petitioners humbly call upon the Senate to support, or, if necessary, to initiate a Federal Inquiry into South-West Tasmania.

Your petitioners also call upon the Federal Parliament not to allocate or allow funds to be raised for construction of dams in the South-West of Tasmania but to provide such funds as would enable the preservation of this area. This is a national asset and Tasmanians should not be made to bear any financial burden resulting from its preservation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Sir John Carrick (from 739 citizens), Chaney (from 67 citizens), Dame Margaret Guilfoyle (from 587 citizens), Jessop (from 88 citizens), Messner (from 121 citizens), Primmer (from 9 citizens) and Withers (from 43 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Postal Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Victoria respectfully showeth: That the plan by the Australian Postal Commission to downgrade postal and mail services throughout Australia, will place in jeopardy the existing services and the security of the mails by:
downgrading a large number of official post offices;
reducing the number of post offices open for business during the lunch period;
reducing the number of street posting boxes;
delaying telegrams by reducing the number of delivery offices;
downgrading post office services by employing untrained and unqualified staff; and
using private contractors for mail cartage.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government will take immediate action to prevent the Australian Postal Commission implementing any plan which will downgrade the postal and mail services of the citizens of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Chipp (from 9 citizens) and Robert Ray (from 8 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth: That we request that the Government take immediate steps to relieve the burden of increased mortgage costs resulting from increasing home loan interest rates.

We find that the resultant increases in mortgage payments have unduly caused a reduction in the standard of living, reflected in the severe difficulty experienced in meeting household budgetary commitments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should-
1. Maintain Government regulation of bank interest rates.
2. Amend the relevant Acts to provide for a mortgage payment subsidy scheme, based on a 'needs' requirement.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Defence Service Homes Loans: Ex-servicewomen
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That the members of the Women's Services of the 1939-45 War not at present considered eligible for Defence Service Home Loans should qualify as 'Australian Soldiers' under the Defence Service Homes Act. They volunteered for service with the Naval, Military and Air Forces, serving wherever they were sent in whatever capacity they were required and yet are refused Defence Service Home Loans.

They took the oath to resist His Majesty's enemies which meant to fight His Majesty's enemies, and although not used in actual combat in war zones, they were available for that use and had a sufficiently grave need arisen would have been used, to serve with distinction as have women of other lands.

In accordance with the Acts and regulations of the period, the women of the Military Forces had enlisted for service anywhere, some of the Naval women to sail in any waters, others with service on warships optional, while the women of the Air Force could have been sent to Papua New Guinea or other territories under the control or care of Australia.

Ex-servicemen of the Royal Australian Navy, the Australian Imperial Force and the Royal Australian Air Force who volunteered in the 1939-45 War but were not sent to War Zones are granted home loans. Not to grant eligibility to all Ex- servicewomen of 1939-45 War is unjust and unfair.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that you favourably consider amending the Defence Service Homes Act by repealing Sub-section 4 (2A) (b) (c) (d) of the Principal Act as amended by No. 137 of 1978, and grant eligibility to all members of the Women's Royal Australian Naval Service, the Australian Women's Army Service, the Women's Auxiliary Australian Air Force, the Australian Army Medical Women's Service, and the Voluntary Aid Detachment of 1939-45 War.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensioner Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the President of the Senate in Parliament assembled the petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth: That it is clearly apparent that Australian society is becoming more polarised-that the rich at home and abroad are becoming richer, profiting from Australia's mineral wealth, whilst pensioners and the disadvantaged, some three million people, are becoming a race apart.

That, of necessity, the Federal Government take action that all Australians share the wealth of their country by the transfer of resources to income security, health care and housing therefore, your petitioners urge that:
1. All pensions and benefits be raised to at least 30 per cent of the National Average Male Earnings seasonally adjusted.
2. Removal of the means/income test on the Pensioner Health Benefit imposed by Federal legislation 1973.
3. Reintroduction of Medibank in so doing restore all Australians to equality of citizenship.

4. To alleviate Australia's shortage of housing stock within the capacity of people to pay (rental and ownership) the Federal Government immediately inject $ 200 million into State Housing Authorities, which will, in addition, alleviate unemployment.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Bjelke-Petersen (from 60 citizens), Hamer (from 128 citizens) and Ryan (from 61 citizens).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of the sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate supports the holding of a further session of the Australian Constitutional Convention in Adelaide this year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate condemns the Government for failing to maintain the real value of pensions and social security benefits, placing an excessive economic burden on those dependent on government payments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its grave concern at the mismanagement of the economy by the Government, reflected in the fact that:
1. 6.4 per cent of the workforce-or 437,000 people-are unemployed;
2. 146,000 teenagers-or 21.2 per cent of the teenage workforce-are unemployed;

3. private houses under construction have fallen by 12 per cent in a year, public houses under construction in December were 11 per cent fewer than a month earlier and housing approvals in the State of Victoria are the lowest since 1962 ;
4. interest rates are escalating rapidly;
5. sharemarkets are at their lowest level for two years; and
6. overseas reserves have fallen by $2,000 million.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its concern at the Government's failure to fulfil its promise to abide by the terms of the Bowen Report on Pecuniary Interest of Ministers and members of parliament, notably provisions that:
(a) a Minister should inform the Prime Minister when a potential conflict of interest arises in the administration of his department;
(b) a Minister should not hold shares in a company which deals with his department.
It is noted that the Minister for Primary Industry admits that he:

(i) did not inform the Prime Minister that a potential conflict of interest was involved in his holding of some 1,200 shares in the Murray-Goulburn Co-operative , an organisation that had dealings with his department; and
(ii) that the Minister continued to hold shares in the Murray-Goulburn Co- operative while he made decisions about the company's production of over-quota butter.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. I ask: What are the three essential elements of the Government's wages policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —A little later today I will be putting down a statement on various matters which are the responsibility of the Minister for Industrial Relations. That touches also on the question of wages policy. I suggest that honourable senators hold their patience until I put down that statement.

—I ask a supplementary question. In view of the fact that I have had the advantage of being forewarned of the contents of the statement, which does not deal with the essential elements of the Government's wages policy, I repeat the question: What are the essential elements of the Government's wages policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I repeat my answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer the Minister to an article on page 1 of this morning's Sydney Morning Herald entitled 'Hawke, Hayden Blaze Away in Caucus' and to the variation and diversity of opinion which exists in the Parliamentary Labor Party as to its platform in relation to capital gains tax. I therefore ask the Minister: Does his Government have a definite policy on capital gains tax? If so , can he give the Senate a brief resume of such definite and clearly defined policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen Press reports indicating a conflict of viewpoint between Mr Hawke and Mr Hayden. I am aware that any recent suggested change in policy on capital gains tax by the Australian Labor Party cannot be enforced because it is a matter for the Labor Party conference, which can well override such a suggestion. We have a Labor Party which is committed to increased tax in a wide variety of ways. Mr Hayden is on record as saying that he personally is a high tax man. That is his own statement. Indeed, other members of the Labor Party are on record as saying that when-if ever, Mr President-they get back into government it will be necessary to increase taxes. Quite clearly, the Labor Party is a high tax party. The Liberal Party and the National Country Party as a coalition have made it clear that they are opposed to a capital gains tax.

—I ask the Minister representing the Prime Minister another question on the subject of taxation. I ask whether the Prime Minister has noted that Professor Russell Mathews recently described the Australian tax system as one which discriminates in favour of speculative activity and against enterprise and thrift, gives preference to foreign taxpayers over Australian residents, redistributes income from the poor to the rich, consciously discriminates against wage and salary earners and provides a major stimulus to wage inflation and industrial conflict. Does the Government take seriously these criticisms by a man previously hailed by Mr Fraser as a brilliant tax analyst? Will the Government take some action to ameliorate the inequity and inefficiency of the taxation system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clearly, I cannot say whether the Prime Minister has taken notice of Professor Mathews's statements, nor indeed am I able to say that Senator Walsh in his question gave an accurate precis of Professor Mathews's statements. On both of those matters I am unable to comment. But I am able to say that unlike the Labor Party-in its years in office it did nothing to reform the taxation system, did nothing to pursue tax evaders and, in fact, created a gross inequity by allowing the harvesting of taxation through inflation to create a complete distortion in a system which included about seven levels in the taxation scale-we have made a series of tax reforms over the period. By contrast we have been major reformers.

ANSWER.PARA: We quite understand that inflation creates distortions in the tax system. Indeed, we had been proceeding with half indexation. Of course we want to produce tax relief. We have made very major endeavours by way of savings in public expenditure to provide that. Unfortunately, we have not been able until now to provide a sufficiency of accommodation to bring about tax relief. But we are a coalition which is dedicated to sound tax reform and tax relief.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Firstly, to set the record straight, I would like it to be noted that I was quoting Professor Mathews's own words, so the question of accuracy of interpretation does not arise. Secondly, does Senator Carrick realise that Professor Mathews was commenting upon the taxation system as it is, after all the alleged reforms to which Senator Carrick just referred had been implemented?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Largely because I was overseas on Government business in recent weeks, I have not seen--
—It will not be long before you are overseas permanently, so we are told.

—As usual, Senator McLaren's information is totally wrong. One is not surprised to have revealed what he is told. I was overseas in relation to energy matters and, therefore, I did not have the opportunity to study a report which was apparently put out during that time. Therefore, I am unable to comment on the report, but I have no doubt at all that, if Professor Russell Mathews found cause to criticise distortions in the present tax system, he would have written a best seller about the much graver distortions of the past.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. I refer to my question without notice of 19 August 1981 relating to the report of the independent inquiry, conducted by Sir Clarrie Harders after October 1980, which investigated matters relating to the disclosure of electoral expenditure in accordance with the Government's commitment to public disclosure. I remind the Minister that in August 1981 the report was under Government consideration and that no decision had then been made as to its public availability. Firstly, has the Government since made a decision in respect of Sir Clarrie Harders's recommendations, and if so when will that decision be disclosed? Secondly, when will the Harders report be made available to members of the Parliament and the public generally?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall Senator Missen's question last year-he said it was asked on 19 August-concerning the Harders inquiry into the disclosure of electoral expenditure. It is with some diffidence that I say to Senator Missen that the matter is still under Government consideration. In fact, it is still under active Government consideration. I understand from the television show Yes Minister that if a matter is under consideration it means that the file has been lost and if it is under active consideration it means that people are looking for it. That is not the case. The matter is actively under consideration at present. I cannot yet say when a decision will be made, when it will be announced or when the report will be made publicly available. Those three questions will now be sent to the Minister whom I represent in this place.

—Is the Minister for Veterans' Affairs aware of expert medical evidence that Australian Vietnam veterans are suffering toxic brain dysfunction as a result of their service and that this involves them in a variety of unpleasant and disabling symptoms? Is he aware that this brain poisoning is said to be clearly distinguished, by recognised tests, from war neurosis and other areas of purely psychological cause and that a clear profile of symptoms is said to exist? This profile has been evident in research in four overseas countries and may also be evident in as many as 600 Vietnam veterans in Australia. In view of these facts and the severe nature of the symptoms of this toxic brain dysfunction, what urgent plans does the Government now have to identify its extent in Australia and provide research and ultimately treatment in this area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Mason made no reference to any authority for his assertions in this area. I take it that he could produce the information which he claims to have. I have no specific information on the point that he raises but I would like to make one or two general points in connection with the problems of Vietnam veterans. The Government's policy is to develop methods by which Vietnam veterans can receive counselling and treatment through repatriation general hospitals. Of course, as of our announcement yesterday, they will be able to receive treatment in country hospitals where they are required to do so when they are in urgent need. These are measures of the Government's concern for these problems and we are endeavouring to improve things as we develop our systems day by day.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the means by which we may be able to detect the kinds of problems which Senator Mason refers to, we have in place several studies of Vietnam veterans, their families and children. I hope the results of those studies will resolve the kinds of problems to which he alludes. If he has further information in respect of his particular concern which he would care to make available to the Government, I would be only too pleased to hear from him.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister aware that the facts I mentioned were given in evidence to a recent hearing in Melbourne of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment and were freely reported in the Australian Press at that time?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, Mr President, but I ask the honourable senator to provide the information to me.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Is it a fact that the pay increases granted last year to the armed Services will be of the order of $160m this financial year and over $ 250m next year? How is this increase going to be funded? Can the Minister assure the Senate that there will be no degradation of general conditions of service in the armed Services, such as food rations, that there will be no cuts in training programs or in fuel usage and that there will be no reductions in equipment acquisitions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator MacGibbon has asked for a fair amount of information in relation to the armed Services and plans to meet the salary increases that have been provided for them. I will have to refer the question to the Minister for Defence. I think it would be preferable to have a detailed answer from him.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Recently released statistics show that Australia has the highest inflation rate for five years, the highest taxation rate ever, the highest interest rates ever, the highest unemployment rate since the present Australian Bureau of Statistics began collecting data, economic growth way below Budget predictions, a rapidly falling rate of home building, a very large current account deficit and rapidly falling overseas reserves, and that all economic indicators are moving in the wrong direction. Can the Government find any reason to believe that this alarming trend will be reversed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Elstob could not have read the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development report on Australia recently published; otherwise he would not have made that statement. The report, whilst drawing attention to increased inflation in Australia, nevertheless showed that Australia's performance in the management of its economy was much more favourable than that in the great majority of OECD countries. In fact, it is a matter of how Senator Elstob should look at this. For example, if one were to compare today's figures for inflation and other matters with the figures for the years 1973, 1974 and 1975 one would see that today we are admirably situated by contrast and that the inflation rate today is significantly less than it was under the Whitlam-Hayden Labor Government. So, if Senator Elstob finds the inflation rate today one for criticism, he should, in fact, condemn the performance of his own party, which had a disastrous record at that time. I suggest that he look at those figures.
—I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister dispute the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures? Does he believe that they are wrong?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be very happy to put out the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures for 1973, 1974 and 1975 and for recent years to show the contrast. I do not dispute the ABS figures. I do not have them before me. But I repeat that, by contrast with the performance of the Whitlam-Hayden Labor Government, we have managed very well indeed. The OECD has commented that by contrast with the performance of other countries we are favourably managing and that this country is under good management. It is true that there are pressures on inflation that we want to relieve. I hope that all who have any influence at all will bear down on the industrial unrest in this country which is causing unduly high costs, and on the pressure upon wages which is forcing prices up. Indeed, if one were sincere in wanting to have relief of inflation one would work towards those goals.

—I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Health. In view of a recent report from a Sydney hospital that 23 per cent of drivers admitted to that hospital following car accidents showed the effects of smoking cannabis, will the Minister seek to have Australian Capital Territory drivers involved in accidents tested initially for both alcohol and cannabis and thus ensure that similar penalties, remedies and/or deterrents are used in either case? Will the Minister seek similar treatment of the problem Australia- wide through the Health Ministers Council? Can the Minister say what steps have been taken to implement the findings of the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Road Safety on alcohol, drugs and road safety in this area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator's question is in several parts. I may not have information on all parts of the question. I am aware of the study which was conducted in the northern suburbs of Sydney, at the Hornsby and Ku-ring-gai Hospital, on a number of casualties-almost 100 I think. It showed the presence of cannabis metabolites in about a quarter and alcohol in a number when their urine was tested. It is difficult to know exactly what the significance of the figures for cannabis is because the breakdown products continue to be excreted for weeks after people have smoked cannabis. Nevertheless, a report of a committee of the Senate expressed concern about cannabis smoking and motor car driving. I understand that the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Road Safety has also drawn attention to this problem. I will put to the Minister for Health the question that the honourable senator has raised about possible action in the Australian Capital Territory. I think it would be his view at present that it would be premature to move straightaway to introducing the kinds of measures suggested by Senator Archer. However, the suggestion that it may be a requirement to gather more information and to get a better view of the scene is one that has merit and one that I think the Minister would want to look at more closely.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. In a television interview on 3 February Mr Fraser said that tax cuts would lead to 'more money floating around in the economy' and therefore more inflation. Does this mean that the Prime Minister has now abandoned his often- stated belief that higher taxes induce higher wage demands and add to inflation? If it does not mean that, what does it mean?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister, as I understand it, was commenting on the present situation in the light of the present Budget and the deficit. The aim of bearing down on inflation and interest rates is, of course, to reduce the deficit in the Budget so that there is no necessity to borrow openly and compete in the market thereby forcing up interest rates and the cost of money. Therefore the application of the Budget strategy, which was praised, incidentally, by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, was a bearing down to provide the anti-inflationary pressures and also to provide room for the private sector to borrow. The Government was referring to that point in time. If in the future and if in the contemplation of the Budget ahead the Government should find itself capable of providing sufficient revenue for tax cuts the Government would clearly have before it its desire to ensure that the people of Australia receive tax cuts. I remind honourable senators that during the period from 1976 to 1978 the Government did make significant reforms in the tax system. Indeed those reforms contrast very starkly with those of the past, much in the favour of this Government.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I believe that the Minister did not refer to the last part of my question in which I asked: Does this mean that the Prime Minister has now abandoned his often-stated belief that higher taxes induce higher wage demands and add to inflation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that the Prime Minister and the Government hold the view that higher taxes have a detrimental effect in reducing the purchasing power of the family and therefore being an incentive to make higher wage demands. It would be a very useful thing indeed if it were possible to make room for tax cuts but at this moment tax cuts could be made in only two ways: Either by substantially increasing the deficit and thereby forcing much greater pressure on public borrowing and therefore forcing interest rates up higher to the great detriment of home purchasers by robbing them of their wages, or by cutting expenditure. I have not heard Opposition senators suggest any avenue in which expenditure could be cut by in the order of $500m to $700m. If they have any such suggestion they might indicate it to us. There are only two ways to do this. One is to increase the deficit, which we reject. Sadly it is being blown out anyhow because of industrial unrest, unduly high wage rates and other matters, but if it blows out further it will put pressure upon public borrowing. Indeed what the Australian Labor Party would be advocating would be higher payments for home purchasers. We would reject that.

—I direct a question to the Minister for National Development and Energy. I refer him to recent announcements of increased oil exploration this year and to the Government's policy of import parity pricing. Does the Minister believe that this activity, which apparently envisages a doubling of wells drilled this year and an expenditure on exploration in the vicinity of $800m, has come about as a direct result of the Government's import parity pricing policy? Is it likely that this will result in a substantial increase in Australia's oil reserves and production? If so, will the Government consider reviewing its policy on import parity to take these successes into account? Further, can the Minister advise the Senate whether it is correct that should the Australian Democrats block legislation increasing crude oil levies this would provide major oil producers with a windfall profit of about $45m, thereby denying the Government the same amount in revenue, detracting from its financial situation and making it more difficult for it to reduce personal taxation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The oil exploration bodies have recently published quite exciting information regarding the huge increase in both the money to be spent on exploration and development and the number of exploration wells and development wells to be undertaken. Indeed, this shows, as Senator Jessop said, a doubling of effort compared with the previous year and an enormous increase in these efforts since the last year of the Labor Government. It is true that the Government is emphatic that this has come about because of its import parity pricing policy. It is quite clear that that is so. Indeed, all the explorers and developers themselves indicate quite clearly that it is as a result of import parity pricing that they are doing this and they would not do it otherwise.

ANSWER.PARA: There has been some initial success-not sufficiently developed at this moment to be measured in terms of its long term benefits-some initial definition of fields and some prospect that there will be some very useful small to moderate fields that may well offset the decline of Bass Strait fields. But we are still a long way from any point of complacency. It is fundamental that we should keep up the pressure of exploration and development. Therefore, we should keep up the pressure of our policies bearing on this matter. Our policies of import parity pricing have worked. They provide for Australia's oil and gasolene to be sold at less than half the average price in overseas countries with which we trade. We are, in fact, finding petroleum energy and at the same time providing energy at a cost much lower than costs in the countries of our trading partners.

As to the effect of what has been foreshadowed as an action of the Democrats, one would need in the first place to understand what they intend to do. I do not believe at this moment that they will find that they have another error of judgment. I cannot believe that the Democrats who went to the people in 1980 saying that they would never oppose a policy for which a government had a clear mandate could reject import parity pricing, which was the main policy on which the election was fought. If ever there was a policy for which a government had a mandate it is import parity pricing. I do not know whether we will hear that the Democrats have made an error of judgment. I will need to find out what their policies are as they unfold. The legislation that we will put to the Parliament will be the normal validating legislation introduced in this half of the year to validate the rises in price over the whole of the year. One of the effects that could very well arise from the rejection of the legislation would be to leave in the hands of the oil producers very substantial sums of revenue which ought to be in the hands of the Government to spend on the taxpayers and presumably to give tax relief.

Where communities have an established structure , a consensual basis of decision making and where it can be seen to be susceptible to democratic control it seems to have worked quite well.

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. I again raise the issue of the importance for South Australia of the quality and quantity of water available for domestic and agricultural use. In the few months since the advent of the new River Murray Agreement last November have there been useful developments towards better solving this problem? I ask in particular about recent reports concerning freshwater studies and desalination research by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the decisions made upon the adoption by the States and the Commonwealth of the new Agreement was that the terms of the Agreement would be carried out straight away and that there would not be a delay whilst the legal processes were put in force; in other words, that we would not wait for the Agreement to be put into law. This has been done. There is now wide testing of the quality of the water. The significant situation is that the Agreement makes an insistence upon quality, and this is being undertaken now in a significant way. A computer model of the river system is set up for examination. Additional undertakings of the Maunsell recommendations are being carried out. In addition, it is significant that the Dartmouth Dam has moved towards a substantial holding of water. It is not wholly full but the situation is, nevertheless, much more reassuring than in the past. There has been a considerable flush of water down the Murray and the salinity of the Murray today is significantly lower than it was for quite a while. It is fair to say that even in its most precarious situation last year the saline content, whilst higher than one wanted, was less than it had been in the past. So some pressures have been working.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the things that will have to be watched very carefully is the use of Snowy Mountains water for hydro-electric schemes so that irrigation volumes are kept in mind throughout the winter period. The Commonwealth announced some time ago that it would invite all States in Australia to undertake with it an overview of water needs in Australia up to the turn of the century. That dialogue is now taking place with the States. We hope that within a year we will have that data because fresh water is significant for the future of not only agriculture but also industry. We have also been looking at the mechanisms that lie within the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, the Australian Atomic Energy Commission and my Department. The CSIRO is in the process of locating all the research into water which is carried out in many of its sections, to see whether it can better organise that research. My Department and the Atomic Energy Commission are in consultation. A discussion is going on at the moment with the Australian Water Resources Council about a report on water research which we hope will be before the State Ministers fairly soon.

A great deal of work is being done now in the overall quantitative and qualitative measurement of water in Australia. I hope to be able to report substantial progress towards the total overview in Australia in the early months ahead and the rationalisation of the various researches that are being undertaken. This will be a very significant step forward in the understanding and qualitative control of water in Australia.

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. I refer the Minister to the report of the Committee of Inquiry into Electricity Generation and Sharing of Power Resources in South East Australia. The chairman, in his foreword to the report, when referring to evidence that a nuclear power plant would not currently offer a cost advantage to Victoria over a coal powered plant, nevertheless offered the advice that in view of possible developments in the field of nuclear power during the coming decade it would seem a prudent provision by the Commonwealth and State governments to develop and agree on the necessary legislation and regulations to license and control such installations against the time when they may have become an acceptable alternative. Does the Minister see merit in the advice of the chairman of the Committee? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.
