PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Walsh proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The inequitable distribution and record level of taxes being imposed by the Fraser Government.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the present Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) released his policy speech for the 1975 elections, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: For three dark years, our freedom, our prosperity, the self-respect of many Australians have been eroded-eroded by the highest taxes in our history.

When that statement was made, personal income tax amounted to 12.7 per cent of gross domestic product. The estimate for this year by the Government is 13.9 per cent. So taxes, as a proportion of gross domestic product, have increased by 10 per cent under the Government of the man who said that taxes had destroyed out self-respect, our prosperity and our freedom. Alternatively, total taxes, which were 23 per cent of gross domestic product when the Fraser Government was elected, have increased to 27 per cent. The estimated income tax revenue for this year is $20.86 billion-that is, just over $20,000m-which is 93 per cent of the total tax collected by the Labour Government in the financial years 1973-74 to 1975-76. In one year this Government, which was elected on a fraudulent promise of lower taxation, is collecting in personal income tax as much as 93 per cent of what the Labor Government collected in three years. It was a fraudulent promise. That is what the aggregate figures show. But it is a lot more significant and meaningful if one looks at the effect of these rapacious tax policies upon the individual.

Let us look, for example, at the single income family on 85 per cent of average weekly earnings-a single income family of four persons. This is the family unit idealised by the Fraser Government and about which the Fraser Government purports to be primarily concerned. If taxation rates as a proportion of income had remained where they were in 1975 that family would be paying $19 a week less in taxation than it is paying now. In real terms there has been an 81 per cent increase in the income tax collected from this idealised family on 85 per cent of average weekly earnings which, incidentally, just happens to be what statisticians call the mode. That is the income level at which the highest concentration of wage earners is found. There are more people on 85 per cent of average weekly earnings than any other level of income. This is where it hits hardest. This is where it hits the greatest number of people.

Alternatively, if we look at average weekly earnings-approximately one-third of all wage earners are on average weekly earnings or above-we find that these taxpayers are paying $1,200 a year more in income tax than they would be paying if the 1975 levels of taxation had been sustained. By that I do not mean the 1975 tables. If the same proportion of income was taken in taxation in 1981 as was taken in 1975 these people on average weekly earnings would have $1,200 more take-home income than they in fact have. It is a highly significant figure because on looking back through some of the previous speeches by the present Prime Minister, we see that in July of 1975, just before he became Prime Minister, he said:
If the person on average weekly earnings were taxed at the rate of 10 years ago , he would be taking home another $1,000 a year in wages.

If the person on average weekly earnings today were taxed at the same rate as he was taxed not ten years ago but six years ago he would be taking home an extra $ 1,200 a year in wages. Back in 1975 Mr Fraser continued:
No wonder the person on average earnings finds it difficult to save the deposit for a house, buy the best education for his children, look after his ageing parents as he would wish.

They no longer find it difficult to do those things; they find it impossible to do those things. Mr Fraser promised, again in 1975, that he would end what he used to call the secret tax of inflation. We heard a lot about the secret tax of inflation from Mr Fraser in those days. Astonishingly, we even heard something about it from Senator Sir John Carrick this afternoon. In the 1975 policy speech Mr Fraser said:
Failure to adjust the progressive income tax schedule for the effects of inflation will lead to acceleration in the rate of wage increases.

As well as robbing people of their hard earned incomes in 1975, according to Mr Fraser excessive levels of personal taxation induced demands for higher wages and therefore higher levels of inflation. It is interesting to note that he is now saying the opposite to what he said then. Of course the promise for full tax indexation-the absolute promise, the solemn promise to end what he used to call the secret tax of inflation-was unceremoniously buried in May of last year. He used to say, not just in 1975 but even in 1977, that lower taxes were an essential prerequisite for economic recovery. On 22 November that year, again significantly during an election campaign, he said:
We have taken the view that a reduction in the personal tax burden is essential to economic recovery and to boosting job opportunities.

That belief, like tax indexation, has been obviously dumped by the Prime Minister because the 1981 Budget increased taxes on wage and salary earners by no less than 22 per cent-a telling demonstration of the effects of what the Prime Minister used to call the secret tax of inflation actually in operation following the one-third indexation of the taxation schedule at the beginning of this financial year. The effects of the secret tax of inflation will be significantly greater next year unless the taxation schedule is indexed. Indeed, if wages increase at the rate forecast by the Government in the Budget Papers, if there is no indexation and if the consumer price index increases by between 11 per cent and 12 per cent as the Budget forecast-it seems likely to do that- there will be a real increase in personal taxation of $1,400m. In other words, the secret tax of inflation will collect automatically in the next financial year an extra $1,400m of revenue for this Government. The corollary of that is that any so-called tax cuts which might be introduced in the latter half of this calendar year which amount to less than $1,400m will, in fact, be hidden tax increases. They will not be presented as that, of course, but that is what they will be.

My comments so far about the present record level of taxation refer only to income tax. To complete the picture one should add the $3 billion increase in the petroleum excise, which this Government has imposed in the last few years, and perhaps the $900m in a full financial year which it seeks to impose because of the sales tax increases and extensions introduced in the 1981 Budget which incidentally, contrary to claims made by at least one of the Government spokesmen in the House of Representatives, have a highly regressive effect on income distribution. If one looks at statistics on the highest income group surveyed by the Australian Bureau of Statistics and published in the latest Survey of Household Expenditure one finds that those sales tax increases will account for something less than 0.5 per cent of the household income of those highest income households and for slightly over one per cent of the household income of the lowest income households. In other words, the poor will pay proportionately twice as much as the rich as a result of those sales tax increases. That again is the aggregate.

That information does not mean so much in the aggregate as it means when it is actually applied at the level of the individual citizen. When we put all of these things together and adjust for inflation we find that this idealised family of four with a single income of 85 per cent of average weekly earnings is , as a result of the taxation policies of this Government, paying an extra $19 a week in income tax, an extra $10 a week in petrol tax, an extra $10 a week in interest charges if it has a $30,000, 25-year housing loan, and an extra $10 a week in health insurance premiums. So, this idealised family is paying $50 a week more tax than it was paying in 1975 when Mr Fraser said that our self- respect, our prosperity, had been destroyed by record levels of taxation. He said that it had been eroded by the highest taxes in our history.

The Government still likes to talk about allegedly high taxes in the middle 1970s. It would rather dwell in the past than in the present. Given its dismal record of failure that is not surprising. But if taxation was at punishing and unjustifiably high levels in 1975, how can anyone in this Government justify the very much higher levels of taxation over which the Government is presiding right now? How will Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, or anyone else who is to follow in this debate, justify the collection of policies which have imposed on this idealised family of four with a single income of 85 per cent of average weekly earnings an extra $49 a week in taxation? That is precisely the set of circumstances over which Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle and this Government preside. We know, of course, that in 1977 the Prime Minister said: 'Interest rates will fall by 2 per cent over the coming year. It is a target that can and will be met'. They are his exact words.

When he said that, the average interest rate for a housing loan was in the vicinity of 11 per cent. It depended upon whether it came from a building society or from a savings bank and it still does. That figure of 11 per cent was the mean figure which required weekly payments of $74 for a $30,000 loan on a 25 -year term. The same loan of $30,000 on a 25-year term and at an interest rate of 14 per cent-which is the mean figure now-requires a repayment of $90 a week with $16 a week being lost in interest for the typical householder taking out a new loan. Indeed it could be validly argued that it is somewhat more than $16 a week. Because of the intervening inflation the actual loan which is taken out has increased so the house purchaser is paying a much higher rate of interest on a substantially higher principle.

The income tax burden is frightful in the aggregate-a very large increase in the proportion of the gross domestic product which is consumed by the Government in taxes. It ought to be a matter of shame to any Liberal or National Country Party politician who asserted a few years ago that it was intolerably high then. But it is even worse in detail because this enormous aggregate burden of taxation has been progressively shifted to an increasing degree to the middle and lower income groups. It has been shifted for three reasons because of deliberate policies by the Fraser Government designed to increase the taxation burden on the middle and lower income groups with, of course, the corollary to reduce tax levels for the very rich-a deliberate policy compounded by stealth by what the Prime Minister used to call the 'secret tax of inflation'. A progressive income tax schedule not adjusted for continuing inflation does two things: It automatically increases the proportion of income paid in tax by all people and it automatically increases by the most the proportion paid by the lower income groups.

According to Professor Mathews the tax burden has been redistributed regressively because of widespread tax evasion and avoidance amounting currently to some $7 billion a year. That is about one-third of the total personal income tax collected by the Government. It has also been shifted regressively because of deliberate policies and provisions written into the Income Tax Assessment Act by this Government-policies such as the investment allowance which is costing the revenue around $450m a year; the ludicrous film industry taxation rort which the Prime Minister picked up from the make-up girl in a television studio in Sydney which is costing in the vicinity of $30m a year; and such taxation avoidance and evasion measures provided for Pitt Street farmers as income equalisation deposits under which Pitt Street farmers and half of the members of the Fraser Cabinet lend the Government $10,000 for one year, borrow $15,000 for two years and pick up a cash bonus of $4,500, half of which is non-taxable. That rort, deliberately written into the Act by this Government-I might add with the assistance of the Australian Democrats and the tax dodgers' friend, Senator Harradine-is not the result of a bizarre interpretation of the taxation Act by an incompetent or a corrupt High Court under the tutelage of Sir Garfield Barwick but the consequence of provisions deliberately and consciously written into the Act by this Government.

A Pitt Street farmer and a Cabinet Minister can borrow $15,000 for two years, lend $10,000 for one year and pick up a $4,500 cash bonus, half of which is non- taxable. This Government, which condemned a previous government for imposing allegedly excessive levels of taxation has in fact imposed, is imposing and will continue to impose, the highest and most inequitable tax burden that Australia has ever seen. It presides over the highest ever rates of interest, the highest level of unemployment since the present Australian Bureau of Statistics data has been collected, the highest inflation for five years, rapidly falling economic growth, a collapsing house building industry and a rapid run-down of our foreign reserves. It is a failure and it is time for it and its Prime Minister to be gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance brought forward by Senator Walsh relating to the distribution and record level of taxes is one of importance for discussion. Perhaps it is useful always to discuss in this place matters of such fundamental importance. Levels of taxation and the distribution of the tax burden are great issues which are at the heart of government. They indicate many things. They indicate many things that perhaps were not mentioned by Senator Walsh in his speech today. They indicate the size of government, the expections of government and the way in which government needs to raise the revenues which it requires for the policies and programs for the Australian people. Of course there are matters on which there are many conflicting views in this or in any other community. It would be ridiculous to suggest that there is any person in any community who would not like to see levels of taxation lower than they exist at any time.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walsh continued to quote the figures of 1975 which were quoted in a debate that we had in this place in November last year. When those figures of 1975 are quoted as the levels of tax and the proportions of gross domestic product I must state-as I stated at that time-that if one is to look at that year one must look at the tax that was to be collected and the deficit that was there for the Government and the Australian people to provide for in some way in the future. It was a deficit that the Government of the day was not prepared to fund. It was a deficit that the Government was not prepared to raise funds for, either by personal tax or any indirect tax. It was prepared to come into the House with a Budget and an enormous deficit requiring a form of funding which was not disclosed at that time.

As Senator Walsh has given 1975 figures I repeat that the real figure at which he ought to be looking for that time, having regard to tax on individuals and the unfunded deficit, is 18 cents in every dollar. That is the appropriate figure that he could have given for that time. I think it would be a good thing if the Australian Labor Party, as the Opposition in this country, were to look realistically at the taxing and revenue raising policies of government and then look at what size deficit it would be prepared to have and how that deficit would be funded. I do not want to restate the figures that I stated on 18 November last year because I think they are well known. They ought to have been noted by Senator Walsh. Instead of continually coming into this chamber and talking about the level of tax while disregarding the whole casting of that Budget, he ought to be bringing his figures up to date and looking at how that year affected the economy of Australia and what were the actions of government with regard to its responsibilities.

It is easy to come into this chamber and to criticise what might be the levels of tax but perhaps relative values also ought to be stated. If we are stating levels of tax, amounts of tax per week and so on, we also ought to be looking at how levels of wages have changed from the time relating to some of the statistics which were quoted. Senator Walsh spoke about taxation burdens. He did not mention the fact that real household disposable income increased, in real terms, by $2.7 billion last year. In the current year, another significant increase is expected to occur in the incomes of Australian households. Those figures need to be taken into account. It is pointless Senator Walsh talking about somebody paying $10 more in tax or more by way of some other charge unless he relates those figures in real terms to comparable figures. Senator Walsh mentioned indirect taxes-for example, the $3 billion in excise on petroleum, the sales tax increases and other such things. Perhaps we can say more about some of those things a little later on.

In none of what Senator Walsh said was there anything about alternative policies. We know that the Opposition is prepared to block in this place Bills that raise revenue in an indirect way. It will join with the Australian Democrats to block a Bill that would raise indirect taxes in the form of sales tax-$132m in this year or $330m in a full year. That is another means of revenue raising which gets away from the personal income tax that Senator Walsh has quoted today. Perhaps some of those policies ought to be looked at too. If the revenue is to be raised from the Australian people the mix of that revenue is equally important. It is not good enough to come in here and talk about the level of personal income tax and then not pass Bills that would raise revenue in other forms and provide a greater opportunity to spread the responsibility between direct and indirect taxes.

Senator Walsh mentioned tax avoidance. I think it ought to be stated again that it is this Government which has done as much as possible with regard to tax avoidance. I think it is fair to say that John Howard, as Treasurer, has made a most concerted attack on tax avoidance. We could contrast his efforts with those of the ALP Treasurers, Crean, Cairns and Hayden, who in their turn did not take the measures that have been taken by the present Treasurer to see that those who are seeking to avoid or evade their taxation responsibilities are brought to account through the changes in the legislation which we are able to make. If we look at the levels of taxation I think we would have to say that the Opposition is not concerned about the total amount of taxes paid in this country because, to finance expanding policies, taxation levels under a Labor government would have to increase. Mr Hayden, as Leader of the Opposition, has said that a philosophy of lower taxes is a threat to the socialism that he espouses. That statement was made by the Leader of the Opposition. For one of his front benchers to come in here and talk about levels of tax under this Government without stating how he would reconcile the statements of his own leader, who talks about increasing taxes, seems to me to be a rather peculiar way to deal with this item. I point out that Senator Walsh brought this matter forward for discussion. Mr Hayden has said-and I have quoted this before-that:

The challenge to traditional democratic socialism has been expressed in a number of deeply dispiriting doctrines. One example, is the rapid spread of philosophy based on lower taxes and smaller government.

That, of course, is a philosophy I would find no difficulty in supporting-lower taxes and smaller government-but it is against all of the doctrine of the present Opposition and it is against the statement made by the present Leader of the Opposition. Of course, the shadow Treasurer has made his intentions quite clear with regard to the need to increase levels of taxation. He has made statements to the effect that if the Opposition does not gain office by 1983 it will be a mammoth task to rebuild the public sector and may be an equally mammoth task to convince the electorate that it should pay a higher level of tax to enable Labor to increase the public sector. So, to talk of taxation levels as they are at present under a government with a commitment to maintain as low a level of government expenditure as possible seems to me to be a very strange thing to do especially in the terms in which it has been done in the matter of public importance raised by the shadow Minister for Finance today.

Mr Willis has made his objectives clear. Mr Hayden has made clear his concern with regard to the challenge to democratic socialism. I think that those who sit with Senator Walsh and the Opposition would in no way dispute the fact that the ALP wants an expanded public sector. One can only get that from the funds of the Australian people, whether they are levied by way of personal income tax or indirect taxes. Whatever way it is done, ultimately it is the people of Australia who will pay for that expanded public sector. If the ALP platform commits a Labor government to massive increases in public expenditure then it is the people of Australia who will pay for that particular platform and policy. Such a policy can only be financed in the usual and traditional ALP way, that is , higher taxes, higher deficits and the printing presses-all of those things that we saw in the three years from 1972 to 1975. One can contrast every action of the Fraser Government to cut back the public sector with the Labor Party's approach to government.

I think it is true and fair to say that every action that has been taken by the present Federal Government to cut back the public sector has been vehemently attacked by the Opposition. When we cut out a program that is irrelevant, or cut out or reduce some element of expenditure that could be reduced because of the cost to the Australian community, there is a concerted attack by the Opposition on that element of change. There is a philosophy of big government in the Opposition party. Its own spokesmen can see that big government means higher taxation. I do not think that the figures quoted by Senator Walsh would in any way be the figures he would cast in a Budget if he were given the opportunity to put his philosophies into effect. The figures that he quotes as being the levels of taxation which were collected-he did not look at relative figures in 1975-are not the figures that would provide for the funding of the policies that have been espoused in more recent times by the alternative government. Under the Whitlam Government, in the three-year period Commonwealth Budget outlays soared from 24 per cent to 30 per cent of the gross domestic product. Taxation soared, inflation soared and the deficit soared.

The term of the ALP Government, I think, has become synonymous with economic mismanagement. It was a three-year period in which every statistic that one could measure was damaging to the Australian economy. I do not think we could find a figure we could quote from that period of government that would allow us to expect lower taxes from any future Labor Party government. I do not think Senator Walsh could dispute that because in a recent speech he said as much as that. He made some comments which I will quote in just a moment. The share of public expenditure in the gross domestic product has been wound back by the Fraser Government to about 27.5 per cent. That contrasts with 30 per cent of gross domestic product which was the figure in the period of the Whitlam Government. I repeat that it is 27 1/2 per cent as against 30 per cent during that period of government. I think that ought to be noted. If we are talking about policies, that particular policy is the one that I want to stress. Personal tax collections under the ALP Government rose by 125 per cent over three years. That figure was not cited today by Senator Walsh. Government spending jumped by 20 per cent, 46 per cent and 23 per cent in three consecutive years. None of those figures can give us an opportunity to imagine that low taxation is the policy of the present Opposition.

The regressive nature of some taxes was mentioned by Senator Walsh. He omitted to mention the major reforms that have been made in the personal tax policies of the Fraser Government. We have reformed the income tax scale, reducing it to three steps. We have introduced the rate of 32c in the dollar as the standard rate, reducing the marginal rate for taxpayers on average weekly earnings. We have more than doubled the spouse rebate and increased the sole parent rebate nearly threefold compared with the levels under the Whitlam Government. Gift duties and estate duties-another means by which a government can raise revenue should it wish to do so-have been completely abolished at the Commonwealth level . This Government does not rest on those initiatives which have already been put in place. Indeed, the Government is committed to further reductions in taxation. All the policies quoted by Senator Walsh will be implemented when possible because it is part of the philosophy of the Government to reduce the burden of expenditure and to leave opportunity for further tax cuts. No one should doubt the Government's commitment to reduce the level of public expenditure and consequently to reduce the level of taxation.

No major reforms were mentioned today in any way by Senator Walsh, but reforms have been mentioned outside this chamber. Perhaps we ought to look at those to see the consequences. Despite the Australian Labor Party's platform, which is binding on every Labor parliamentarian, we are led to believe that the Australian Labor Party has dropped its capital gains tax proposal. There are serious divisions in the Labor Party on this matter. Senator Walsh may concede that, but he certainly did not mention it. He did not mention his party's platform. He did not mention that, with the impending Lowe by-election, a statement has been made by the leader of his party. He did not mention that other Labor Party key principles will perhaps be jettisoned in the desperate search for votes in that by-election. I do not know whether the Labor Party's new-found policy on capital gains tax will be able to be upheld, and perhaps honourable senators opposite do not know that either, but recently Mr Hayden was asked on the Channel 9 Sunday program about his pledges at this by-election and whether they would be the same pledges he would give at a future general election. He said:

Oh, gosh no! . . . . in eighteen months time there will be a lot of water under the bridge, social, political and especially economic water, and the policies appropriate to the last election are starting to recede because of changed circumstances.

I imagine that the policies that will be espoused at the Lowe by-election and in the weeks to come will be jettisoned just as the policies at the last election have been jettisoned and just as the capital gains tax proposal has been carefully put under wraps so that it will not be discussed. But people want to know what the policies are. Given the flexibility of the Labor Party on its basic principles under Mr Hayden, who knows what might happen with any policy. Will Senator Walsh be arguing at his party's conference for the reinstatement of the Australian Labor Party's capital gains tax policy? Will he be arguing elsewhere for a different mix of tax than that seen under the present Government ? Will he be looking for ways of raising revenue? Or will he be looking for a deficit such as previous Labor Treasurers were prepared to produce in their Budgets? In Victoria the Australian Labor Party is arguing for the retention of probate duty. I mentioned the action of the present Federal Government in that area of the collection of taxes. The Victorian Premier pointed out recently that Victoria, under an Australian Labor Party government, would be the only mainland State to have probate duty and that that would be an invitation to people to arrange their affairs in such a way as to avoid paying probate duty. We need to ask: What are the Australian Labor Party's policies on raising revenue and how great is its sincerity with regard to tax avoidance?

Senator Walsh has conceded that the Australian Labor Party's policies are frequently regressive. He did not mention that in his speech today because a fairly permanent record is made of things mentioned in this place. I think he was trying to give the contrary impression when attacking the present Government 's policies which he says are regressive. Last November in a speech to the Committee of Economic Development of Australia reported by the Canberra Times Senator Walsh described the Australian Labor Party's policies-not the Government 's policies-as confused and ignorant. Senator Walsh was not altogether complimentary about the Government, which is perhaps to be expected in any speech made by Senator Walsh, but let us go back to what he said about his own party's policies. The Canberra Times reported his speech in the following terms:
The Labor Party, which had an 'affinity for intervention'-
That costs money-
frequently supported policies 'unlikely to foster efficiency and which demonstrably distribute income regressively'.
That was his own quotation as reported in the Canberra Times. He said further:
Labor has no moral problems with intervention and usually manages to maintain its ignorance of the not-infrequent regressive consequences.

That is his own party's policy, but he did not tell us here what he felt the party would do, had it the opportunity to introduce changes to that policy. He said that Labor manages to maintain its ignorance of the not-infrequent regressive consequences of its policies. Further, he said:
The epitome of Labor's confusion is its inability to distinguish between socialism and regimentation.

We were not informed today what he meant by that in terms of tax collections, but Mr Hayden, as reported by the Canberra Times, appeared unperturbed by Senator Walsh's show of dissension in a major policy area. Maybe Mr Hayden agreed with Senator Walsh's view on the regressive consequences of many ALP policies. Perhaps the people of Australia ought to know, because these are the things that are not said in discussions in this place or with frankness anywhere .

The confusion in the ALP's ranks might be acceptable were we talking about issues which are not of great importance. But taxation and the raising of revenue from the Australian people are of fundamental importance and I think Senator Walsh has readily admitted that the policies of his party, presumably in a number of areas, are regressive. He has given us no positive ways in which he would change them. It is probably time that he got his own house in order so that the next time he speaks in this place he can put forward something more positive with regard to the levels of taxation that need to be raised from the Australian people to fund the programs of government which his party apparently wishes to see unchanged and added, as further burdens, to the usual policies of the ALP when it is in office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the matter of public importance submitted by my colleague Senator Walsh today, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The inequitable distribution and the record level of taxes being imposed by the Fraser Government.

First of all, I will make a brief comment on the reply given by the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) to Senator Walsh's speech. Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, not surprisingly, concerned herself less with a defence of her own Government's record in taxation matters than with an attack on what Labor is supposed to have done in the past and what she speculates it is our intention to do in the future. On both matters I think she was quite erroneous. I agree with the Minister when she says that the equity or inequity of the level of taxation is a matter of concern to the entire community. When she says that there are conflicting views on these matters fundamental to our economy, I do not find myself in agreement. At this stage the essence of Senator Walsh's argument is that this is a matter for consensus and not a matter for conflict. Surely nobody in the community says that the level of taxation is not at a record high. Surely nobody-it seems, not even the Minister for Finance herself- can say that the distribution of the taxation burden within our community is equitable. In fact, I do not believe the concept of equity entered into the Minister's comments at all-which of course, is not surprising as the Liberal Party of Australia is concerned with anything other than equity.

I should point out too that it is the intention of the next Labor Government to see not an increase in the burden of taxation on personal income taxpayers but a redistribution of the tax burden according to the principles of equality. Of course, we will want to increase the revenues available to the Government, but we will increase those by measures which are equitable and which involve strategies other than those which increase the burden on the average wage or salary earner. Of course, the latter strategy is the only strategy pursued by the Fraser Government in the last six years.

I return to the subject of the debate-the inequalities in and the high level of taxation under the current system. I remind honourable senators in summary what the Government's current taxation strategy is. In the last Budget the Government provided for a record high outlay of $40.7 billion and for a record increase of taxation of wage and salary earners of 22 per cent. With the addition of the new wide-based sales tax, should the Senate agree to pass it, the Government will extract from the community a record level of government revenues in 1982-83. Those matters, I think, are beyond dispute. It is worth commenting that amongst the records which this Government has achieved is the outlay of a record $40.7 billion.

Although Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle has just given us the stereotype Liberal rhetoric about wanting to move back to small government and wanting to reduce the size of the public sector, it ought to be noted that the public sector is as large now as it ever was and that the amount of public outlay by the Federal Government in its last Budget was larger than that under any preceding government, including any preceding Labor government. So what we have seen really is not a reduction in public expenditure in terms that would be of benefit to the average wage and salary earner but simply a redistribution of outlay of public money away from public services towards areas that subsidise the private sector and that certainly subsidise the high income earners and the very wealthy in this community. The taxpayer is not being saved money; the average taxpayer is simply being denied the services that ought to come from the taxation that he or she is forced to pay.

I draw attention to a particular area of inequality in the Government's taxation strategy. I refer to the effect of the Government's taxation strategy on women. In framing its taxation strategy the Government has demonstrated a total disregard for the unequal burden current tax policies place on Australian women. In fact, so far from the collective mind of the current Government is the welfare of Australian women that I very much doubt whether women, as a separate and disadvantaged group comprising more than half of the Australian population, even entered into consideration when tax policies were formulated. The Federal Government appears to have failed to realise what is evident to increasing numbers of Australian women-that to them, as a very large group suffering economic disadvantage in our society, taxation, as the major means of redistributing income, is a vital issue. To achieve economic equality women must first achieve an equitable tax system-that is, one in which they do not bear a disproportionate tax burden. It is a matter of particular concern to Australian women that the Fraser Government's policies have served to increase the inequities in the current tax system and that the Government displays not the slightest interest in giving Australian women a fair deal on taxation.

I shall outline the current taxation system to demonstrate how it discriminates against women. I refer in particular to three groups of women which comprise almost the entire female population of Australia-that is, women in the paid work force, women who are age pensioners and women in the home. Taking the first group, women as wage and salary earners, I remind honourable senators that Senator Walsh's contribution to this debate established that the tax burden falls heaviest on middle and low income earners. I do not think that matter was refuted at all by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. When we look at that group which is bearing the heaviest burden of pay-as-you-earn taxation we find that women form a disproportionate percentage of low income earners. The 1981-82 Budget figures on taxable incomes of males and females show that while 90 per cent of men earn less than $30,000 per annum, about 90 per cent of women earn less than $15,000 per annum and that 55 per cent of women who pay taxes have incomes of under $10,000 compared with only 27 per cent of men. One-quarter of all women paying tax earn under $7,000 per annum. This reflects women's participation in the part time work force.

The majority of working women are wage and salary earners and as such are paying substantially higher taxes in 1981-82 due to the Government's abolition of full tax indexation. Total income tax collections will rise by $3,134m or 22 per cent in 1981-82. While this means that all taxpayers will pay a greater proportion of their income in tax this year those on low incomes-that is, the majority of women taxpayers-will face the highest percentage increases. For non- PAYE taxpayers-those with business, property and dividend incomes, a group in which women have disproportionate representation-taxes are budgeted to rise by only 5.3 per cent in 1981-82 compared with the 22 per cent rise in tax paid by wage and salary earners. It is clear that lower income earners, the group in which women are over-represented, are bearing the brunt of Fraser's high taxation policies.

When we turn to pensioners and people living on benefits we note that women comprise 65 per cent of those in receipt of pensions and benefits. Of course, the majority of those women would be single age pensioners and a majority of the remaining pensioners would be supporting mothers, that is, women alone bringing up children on a pension. So in both cases we are looking at very disadvantaged groups of women indeed. Fraser Government policies have ensured that the rates of pensions and benefits have lagged well behind community income movements. The majority of those relying on benefits-as I have said, a very large number of them are women-now live in poverty and to exacerbate the situation, because the Government has failed to alter the tax threshold and because of inflation, some pensioners and beneficiaries will this year pay increased taxes and many pensioners and beneficiaries will this year be forced to pay tax for the first time.

Already 250,000 pensioners pay tax. After the May indexation pension increases which will incorporate September and December consumer price index rises, most of their low income colleagues will join them. Single pensioners will be paying tax on any bank or building society interest of more than $6.50 a week. I think that is a fact that deserves exposure throughout the length and breadth of this land. It is not surprising that the Minister for Finance did not mention the concepts of equality or equity in her address when a government is prepared to tax pensioners on that. Pensioners and beneficiaries who have not previously paid tax on their social service payments will face 32c in the dollar tax on any income above the $4,195 threshold level. Every pensioner who has more than $6.50 pocket money on top of the pension will be hit. I remind honourable senators that the majority of people I am talking about are women. It is little wonder that the Government faces defeat in the approaching Lowe by-election. Lowe is an electorate which has a large number of pensioners, particularly women on the age pension. I ask: What incentive would such women have for voting for the Fraser Government whose policies have run pensioners into the ground? In 1980-81 the single person's pension was 23 per cent of average weekly earnings. This year it has fallen to 22 per cent of average weekly earnings. Because the tax threshold has not been altered in this Budget, single pensioners who receive the maximum pension will pay an extra $155.37 tax this year.

I turn to women in the home, a group for whom the Fraser Government professes to have special consideration, a group which is seen by some members of the Fraser Cabinet as exemplifying the way in which they would like women to participate in this society. What has happened to women in the home in response to the Government's taxation strategies? The Government's attempts to increase indirect taxes and to introduce new indirect taxes will, of course, hit everyone but particularly women in the home. It is the Government's intention that housewives trying to cope with a household budget shrunk by higher income tax, expensive health insurance and high mortgage payments will pay more for everything from essential household goods such as refrigerators to items such as shoes and clothing which must constantly be replaced. If the Government's proposals are passed by the Senate, taxpayers will pay an extra $800m in increased sales tax. Although food will not be directly affected, increased taxes on packaging will put food prices up. The tax on furniture, floor coverings, drapery, bedding and white goods will double and shoes and clothing, which were previously exempt, will be subject to a 2 1/2 per cent tax.

The Housing Industry Association estimates that the tax on building materials will add $1,000 to the cost of building and furnishing a new home. The net result of sales tax increases on the average household budget will be a cut of at least $4 a week. And the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has had the audacity to tell us that we will not even notice it. Perhaps the Prime Minister and Mr Howard will not notice it. Those on salaries as high as Mr Fraser's or Mr Howard's will not notice $4 a week. However, to women on low incomes or pensions $4 on top of $11 for health insurance and an average of $15 a week increase in mortgage payments, stemming from interest rate increases in the last Budget, will mean the difference between surviving and not surviving. Interest rates concerning home ownership are, of course, another factor contributing to the deteriorating situation of women in the home and women taxpayers. Many women attempting to buy a home are in a desperate position due to the 1981 interest rate increases and now face the possiblity of further increases in interest rates. Yet the Federal Government has just rejected any suggestion of assisting low income home buyers or potential home buyers through the taxation system or by any other means.

I will look briefly now at the other side of the taxation coin-how taxation revenue is used. In particular, I want to look at the decision by the Government some years ago to abolish child tax rebates and introduce a system of family allowances. Those allowances, because they constitute a redistribution of income from men to women, are the most important redistributive measure for Australian women. However, since the introduction of family allowances in 1976, their real value has been eroded by at least 40 per cent due to the Government's failure to index or raise them. In 1976 the allowance for two children equalled 5 per cent of average male weekly earnings and for four children it equalled 11 per cent. By August 1980 the value of the allowance for two children was equal to 3.7 per cent of average male weekly earnings and for four children it was down to 8.9 per cent. Again women are losing out. I also draw attention to the fact that the amount paid by the Government by way of the dependent spouse rebate is now more than the amount allowed by the Government for family allowances for all families in Australia. When we take into account the fact that the dependent spouse rebate is not needs based and has nothing to do with dependent children and, in fact, 51 per cent of families with dependent children do not receive it, I think it is time to question the equity of a policy of increasing that rebate while refusing to increase or index the family allowances which are the most direct form of assisting women.

In conclusion, I believe that the Government's taxation policies are actively working against the economic interests of Australian women. I believe that Australian women are becoming more and more aware of this. The falling vote by women for conservative parties over the last ten years demonstrates that Australian women are becoming totally disillusioned with the economic and taxation policies of this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was Edmund Burke who once said:

SPEECH.PARA: To tax and to please, no more than to love and be wise, is not given to men.

I suppose that is a truism in any country. But while we live in a structured society the government of the day will always have the responsibility of imposing taxation so that it can implement its plans and try to accede to the wishes of the people who elected it. The matter of public importance that we are discussing today refers to the 'inadequate distribution and record level of taxes being imposed by the Fraser Government'. I think it is fair enough that every so often any government should stop to look at how equitable are its distribution and imposition of taxes. I believe that we have done so. When we took over from the previous Labor Government we had a good look at where this country was going and at the high rates of taxes existing. That Government had almost destroyed rural Australia with its taxes. We decided to alter the taxation mix and have been altering it ever since. I recall that we introduced income equalisation deposits and tax averaging. We allowed write-offs for irrigation in order to get a bit of heart and a bit of production back into rural Australia. Many people have only just realised that when the country hurts in Australia, it is not long before the city hurts too.

One of the things that is excercising our minds at this stage is the recent decision taken by the Government to change the taxation mix and opt for broad based indirect taxation rather than direct taxation. Sales tax has been part of our taxation mix since it was introduced by a Labor government in 1930. Even at that stage sales tax was introduced on food items. Over a period commencing in the middle 1940s successive Liberal and Country Party governments reduced sales tax on food until it was finally abandoned in the 1960s. Let us be quite fair about it. A tax on foodstuffs was imposed by a Labor government. Our side of the political spectrum decided that it was not fair and thus we gradually reduced and ultimately abolished sales tax on food items.

It is generally agreed that in the Australian tax system too much reliance has been placed on direct personal tax. Our overall taxation burden is generally pretty low and that has been brought out by recent Organisation for Economic Co- operation and Development figures. The average taxation burden, as a percentage of gross domestic product, is 35.8 per cent. Australia's rate is 28.8 per cent. I understand that only four countries have a lower overall taxation average than we have and that is a good point in our favour. But what did show up in those Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development figures, which supports our Government's policy in changing the mix, is that we have more emphasis on direct taxation than we have on indirect taxation. That is what we are trying to change. Sales tax has a long term value and we are trying to broaden that base and put greater reliance on sales tax and less reliance on personal income tax as a source of revenue.

Of course, we realise that when the Labor Government was in office it used personal income tax to pay for its grandiose spending programs and high taxation was essential for the Labor socialistic policies. Socialistic governments need high taxation. It is as simple as that. I do not see why the Labor Party should quarrel with that principle. The record in the Budget Papers shows that the total tax grab while the Australian Labor Party was in government grew by $8.4 billion-in other words, it increased by 99 per cent in three years. What is more to the point is that its income tax collections grew by 125 per cent. Those figures are taken straight out of the Budget Papers. They are there for all to see. It is quite interesting that some time ago I had a table prepared showing the after tax income of selected incomes for the single wage earner from 1971-72 to 1981-82. On an income of $5,000 in 1971-72 the after tax income for a single income earner was $3,999. In 1975-76-the year of Mr Hayden's last Budget-the after tax income was $3,790. It was less than in 1971-72. In 1981-82 the after tax income is $4,742. For an income of $7,500 in 1971-72 the after tax income was $5,555. In 1975-76-so much for the Labor Party looking after the low income groups-the after tax income was $5,415 and in 1981-82 it is $6,442. I will look briefly at the figures for an income of $15,000 over the same years. In 1971-72 the after tax income was $9,234. In 1975-76 the figure was $9,790 and for 1981- 82 it is $11,542. It can be seen by looking at those selected figures that in any year the Labor Government's performance was abysmal.

Australia raises 6.1 per cent of its tax revenue from what is known generally as general consumption taxes. In Australia we know it as sales tax. France, Denmark, Norway and Finland raise more than 20 per cent of their revenue in this way. When judging our standards by those in other countries we have good reason to change that tax mix. Tax dodging is a sore point on both sides of the chamber . Both parties recognise the problem. But we cannot avoid sales tax the way it is currently allocated.

Sales tax can be adjusted. This fact is overlooked, I think quite deliberately, when the Opposition tries to make a point. Sales tax can be adjusted to have greater impact on luxury goods than on everyday items. That is the way it is structured. In other words, a greater burden is placed on people who have a capacity to pay than on low income earners. Those who have a capacity to pay cannot dodge it. I cannot argue with that and I do not think the Labor Party would want to either. People tend to buy within their means or their capacity to pay. As I have said, sales tax is levied at a higher rate on certain goods, on goods such as photographic equipment and jewellery. People who buy these goods contribute a greater amount of revenue through sales tax. Low income earners tend to buy cheaper articles and their sales tax contribution is therefore less. I think the point has to be made that the lower income earner is far more protected under the current sales tax provisions than he would be from income tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a lie. That is not true.
—Those who buy cheaper goods pay less. It is as simple as that. If the honourable senator cannot understand that I do not know what he is doing here. It is a point which is overlooked by most people.
—Sales taxes are regressive.
—I understand that sales taxes are progressive under our broad base and the way they are--
—You don't know what the words mean if you understand that.

—I think I probably have a better understanding than the honourable senator. We have sales taxes across a broader range of goods with a higher amount payable on luxury items. Under Labor a family income earner paid more and more taxes as inflation forced him into a higher tax bracket. In her speech Senator Guilfoyle brought out the fact that we had a seven tier system of income tax until we changed it in 1977. —What is your source for that?

—It is out of the Budget Papers. Use your calculator. SPEECH.PARA: If Labor does not gain office at the next election then by 1983, when we could next hope to gain office, we would face a mammoth task in rebuilding the public sector-
Big government again-
and maybe an equally mammoth task in convincing the electorate that it should pay a higher level of tax to enable us to do so.

So the Labor Party is quite unashamedly a high tax party. As I understand it, real after-tax income has increased over the last few years. That represents an increase in after-tax income of 65.1 per cent and 85.6 per cent. Over that period the increase in the consumer price index was 62.5 per cent and 80 per cent respectively. Of course nobody is denying that our taxation receipts have increased. Of course they have increased. More people have joined the workforce and as incomes have increased we have become more affluent and people have bought more and more consumer items. But the point conveniently overlooked is the fact that our outlays have also increased. Our outlay on social security has doubled while we have been in power. Our outlays on defence have doubled while we have been in power. Our outlays on education have almost doubled while we have been in power. Another point conveniently overlooked is the fact that in the last 10 years the deficit has exceeded $3 billion three times and we have gradually reined that in.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two of them under your Government.

—Yes, that is right. We were trying to get the Labor Government' s grandiose schemes back under control. The point that is overlooked is that because of those massive deficits and because of borrowings to finance that deficit the interest on the public debt has tripled since we have been back in power. That is also an outlay that this Government has to meet. Nobody has to destroy the Australian Democrats' credibility; they do it every day for themselves. I reject out of hand the matter of public importance introduced by the Labor Party. I defend quite strongly the role this Government has played during the time it has been in office and the steps it has taken to reduce tax while at the same time meet the expectations of those who rely on it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: -This has been a very sad afternoon. So far we have had from the Government side two speakers who have shown a great lack of economic knowledge and economic philosophy. SPEECH.PARA: Let me refer also to what Senator Collard said earlier about this Government's priorities in expenditure. I refer him to no other authority than Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. I ask the Senate to note that Senator Collard is not content with staying and listening to this expose of his speech. I don't think it is a good idea.

I would like to look at the system of redistribution under this Government. The OECD figures for Australia show tax on corporate income as a percentage of total taxation reducing from 16.66 per cent for 1970 to 10.32 per cent for 1979.

That is a rejection of Government priorities in this area. While looking at this diversion of money from one sector to the other, let us look at some of the other aspects of Government policy implementation which have had an even greater effect on redistribution. Peter Clyne will return from Vienna on the 5th March and will be available for private consultations in Australia for about two months. Brand new fiscal-fiend- proof schemes available, for this financial year and for the future.
For those who are desperate enough and who cannot wait for Doctor Clyne's return the article states:
. . . if the matter is urgent, I can be contacted c/o Hotel Sacher, Vienna.

Under this Government we have seen a massive increase in tax evasion. This is one instance of blatant tax evasion supported and allowed to continue by a Government that shows absolutely no concern. DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Country Party in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report and the transcript of evidence from the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence on the Indo-Chinese Refugee Resettlement-Australia's Involvement.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Country Party in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

It is the first occasion on which I have had the privilege of presenting a report such as this from the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. I seek only to provide an overview of the far greater detail that is to be found in the pages of the report. In December 1976 the Senate Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee tabled its report 'Australia and the Refugee Problem' which dealt mainly with the settlement in Australia of Vietnamese refugees in the turbulent period following the fall of Saigon in April 1975. At that time Australia had accepted about 1000 Indo-Chinese refugees. Now the number is some 60 000. In the years since 1975 Indo-Chinese refugees have become a dominant feature in South East Asian affairs, with significant repercussions for Australia and indeed world-wide. Therefore, the Committee considered it timely that it should be asked to inquire into and report on the Indo-Chinese refugee situation and how Australia has responded to these events.

The advent of the Indo-Chinese refugee problem, at times reaching crisis proportions, brought a positive response from Australia, a humanitarian commitment and an acceptance of these refugees for resettlement. As a consequence, refugee issues have become an important element in Australia's foreign relations, at the bilateral and the multilateral level. We have established ourselves as being prepared to respond constructively to refugee issues and this has undoubtedly raised expectations in others of our role in future refugee situations; a role that is not necessarily confined to our immediate region, for example, our offer to Polish and other Eastern European refugees. How well and in what way we respond to future refugee situations will require careful judgment and will need to take into account the domestic as well as the external factors in determining the nature of any assistance.

Australia's role in the Indo-Chinese refugee situation has had a positive effect on our relations with the member countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations and the Association itself. It demonstrates a willingness on our part to participate in efforts to find solutions to the problems of the region and has helped to break down impressions that selection for settlement in Australia is on a discriminatory basis. The Indo-Chinese refugee problem has not been entirely resolved and there are no guarantees, if conditions in the source countries deteriorate, that the outflow of refugees would not increase dramatically, presenting new problems for the region and beyond. Here again there is a continuing role for Australia to participate in regional and international efforts to avoid a repetition of the past crisis.

Australia has established a reputation in refugee matters not only as a settlement country, but also as an active member of the international community working to find solutions for refugee problems, both at the governmental and the non-governmental level. It can be anticipated that we will be expected to maintain our role and our future participation will have an important bearing on our standing in the international community. The arrival of Indo-Chinese settlers has had an impact on the Australian community. It is the first time that Australians have been exposed to sizable intakes of peoples racially and culturally different from previous settlers. It is a visible difference, yet from the Committee's investigations the evidence overwhelmingly points to a general acceptance of the new settlers. If any resentment or opposition is discernible, it is from isolated sources, involving relatively few people. The Committee received no evidence expressing opposition to Australia accepting Indo -Chinese refugees.

The Committee's inquiry also examined the settlement program for Indo-Chinese refugees coming to Australia. Over the past three years their arrivals have been at the rate of 15,000 per annum. The confused state of events and the urgency of the situation after the Vietnam war gave little time or opportunity to formulate a comprehensive refugee policy or settlement program, nor was there any warning that the refugee exodus would become a crisis. As a consequence, Australia's settlement program has been an evolving one and in many ways needs to be able to cope with changing refugee situations.

The resettlement processes are working well and initial settlement facilities and assistance are of a high standard. Subsequent settlement of refugees into the community is progressing successfully and at a quicker rate than initially anticipated. The Indo-Chinese refugees are regarded as good settlers, anxious to find employment, to further their own and their children's education, and are highly motivated to make a success of their settlement. The proportion of Indo- Chinese seeking to take out Australian citizenship is high compared to most migrant groups.

In the settlement process there are some problems to overcome, such as a lack of English language proficiency among many of the refugees, non-recognition of overseas qualifications and the social, economical and cultural traumas associated with settling into a totally different environment. Government and non-government authorities are aware of such problems and a continuing effort is maintained to alleviate their impact. Witnesses appearing before the Committee pointed out a number of shortcomings in the settlement experience; these varied between locations, some were past problems, others temporary in nature, but most importantly the problems have been identified and solutions are being sought.

It is generally accepted that more could be done in the settlement process if more funds and resources were available. However, the reality of the situation is that both government and non-government resources have limitations and other areas of need exist. Australia's expenditure on Indo-Chinese refugees overseas and for resettlement has exceeded $150m. From the evidence before it, the Committee concluded that the settlement of Indo-Chinese refugees in Australia is progressing well and the new settlers are integrating effectively in this country. The Committee commends Australia's humanitarian commitment to refugees and the work of all government and non-government instrumentalities, organisations, groups and individuals endeavouring to make refugee resettlement successful.

I became Chairman of this Committee half way through this inquiry. I am sure I speak for the present membership when I express our gratitude to former Senator Peter Sim, who was a distinguished Chairman of this Committee for several years, to the late Senator John Knight, whose contribution was immense, and to Senators Kathy Martin, Stan Collard and Kerry Sibraa for their work on this inquiry when members of the Committee. I also thank the present members for their bipartisan approach and their constructive contributions to the compilation of a unanimously agreed to report. Indeed, Mr President, as so often happens, one should add to the contributions of those people the efforts of the staff of the Committee whose contribution was generous and efficient.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to support the remarks of the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence in relation to this report. In fact, I found it a rather easy task to go through the process of this inquiry because, as is well known, the Committee only four or five years ago completed a similiar report. Of course, the whole idea of the task before us was to go back and check over what we perceived to be problems at that stage and to see what had been done and what improvements had been made. I suggest that overall the Committee found that by and large the various Government departments and non-government organisations, in fact everbody concerned with the influx of the 59,000 Indo-Chinese refugees over recent years, had learnt a lot. They had certainly made mistakes but they had agreed to rectify them. I think the Committee generally concluded that the integration of the great bulk of those 59,000 refugees into Australia has gone extremely well. In fact, I recall witnesses repeatedly saying that one of the problems some of the welfare groups concerned with refugees had in relation to Indo-Chinese refugees was that once they left the migrant camps they disappeared into the community intent on getting on in our society. Those organisations found them rather hard to find. Once they freed themselves of the refugee camp they seemed to be content to try to do their own thing, to find work, to get their children into schools, to buy a new car, to pay off a home and to do the sorts of things that I suppose everbody is desirous of doing.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly, there was evidence of some problems, particularly in New South Wales , of a racial nature but it appears that the people concerned have got on top of that and I have heard no more of those reports. One of the other items of evidence that again came from many people in the education field was what they found in relation to Vietnamese or Indo-Chinese children in the classroom. The children were rather reluctant to take time out for a play period. That appeared to be something related to their cultural background and, I perceive, a general desire by those students to study hard to get on, to try to grasp the education system of a new country and to do well.

One matter I wish to take up relates to evidence that was given to the Committee by a group of refugees. It concerns an allegation regarding the treatment of the Hmong people in their own country relative to the alleged use of aerial spraying of hill tribesman with toxic chemicals. This matter has been in the world Press. My suggestion is that it has been put forward by the American authorities in particular. The last report that I saw-a report which could only be considered to be impartial-said that the Americans were hanging their evidence for this allegation against the Vietnamese people on four leaves from trees or shrubs. That is where the allegation lies-on four leaves which have been found to have been discoloured by some means or other. The Americans seem to believe that they can hang an allegation of the use of toxic chemicals by the Vietnamese against the Hmong people on this. I suggest that it is a very weak argument and one that might be worthy of further investigation.

I want to add-I may be digressing slightly but we are talking about refugees- that there are some remarks in the report relative to coastal surveillance. Any reading of the evidence, particularly the in camera evidence, will suggest that there is a lot to be done in the area of coastal surveillance. The matter is far from satisfactory, in my view, and has been raised publicly by other people also . I would suggest that in the event of a further outward bound movement of Indo- Chinese refugees heading towards Australia our coastal surveillance system is not capable of doing the task that it really should and that there is a great amount of room for more government co-ordination and expenditure and perhaps better utilisation of the forces we have, particularly our armed forces, in patrolling our northern coastline. There is, as I said earlier, a great deal left to be desired.

The other matter I want to raise in relation to refugees is this: As we all well know, in post-war years, Australia has been a ready sponge, a ready reservoir, for refugees from countries where the politics are of the left. We have taken anybody, it seems to me, providing they are fleeing from a communist or an alleged communist government. We have been very reluctant to take people from countries where fascist or extreme right wing dictatorships are the vogue. I suggest that relates particularly to refugees from East Timor. I do not believe this Government has done as much as it could well have done to satisfy the wishes of hundreds of East Timorese men, women and children who are desirous of getting out of that country because of the fascist type government that the Indonesians have imposed on them.

By the same token, we have done little or nothing to assist political refugees from South America. South America today is possibly one of the worst areas of the world as far as human rights are concerned. Human rights virtually do not exist in the whole of South America. There are thousands upon thousands of citizens of the various countries that make up that continent who have been shot and who have been tortured and who have fled to other countries, for example, from Uruguay to Argentina. They are thrown into gaols there and tortured and sent back for further torture and mutilation while their relatives and friends here in Australia appeal to the Australian Government for some assistance in getting them out. My friend Senator Mulvihill has plenty of first hand cases in his files relating to men, women and children who fit into that category. I suggest that, if Australia is to play a part in and is to hold up its head in any way at all in relation to human rights around the world, we should be looking to do what we can to try to get people into this country and out of the prison camps and other restrictive devices and mechanisms that fascists can and do use in South America.

Closer to home I do not think we have a very good record. I want to relate some events of about three years ago in West Irian. One Jacob Prai, the leader of a rebel group in West Irian, and one of his lieutenants, Ondawame, were captured on a trip to Papua New Guinea, were hurled into gaol, and tried. It was deemed that they should be deported. I took up with the then Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Peacock, the case for Prai to be given sanctuary in Australia. After all, he was a man who had lived all his life in a tropical climate. But the answer was no and Prai finished up in Sweden. I know for a fact from personal correspondence I have had with Jacob Prai that he is not happy there. I know for a fact that by that very inaction Australia lost a lot of friends. Prai is about as old as I am, and I guess that when I was putting pennies on the plate for missionaries Prai was on the receiving end of them. He was brought up in the Christian belief. He was brought up to believe that Australians were pretty good sorts of people. But I can tell honourable senators that when he finished up as a political refugee in Sweden rather than in Australia he lost all faith in Australians as a people and in Australia as a nation.

Hundreds of political refugees from West Irian have gone into Papua New Guinea and have been turned back, some to their deaths; but we in Australia have done nothing whatsoever about it. The refugees of West Irian are in exactly the same position as the people of East Timor. It seems to me that until this country breaks away from the Americanised subservience that we have towards Indonesia and starts to look at people for what they are-people-we are going to have very some very hard barbs thrown at us in the years to come. Perhaps our children will be the recipients of the hatred that we are now breeding by our reluctance to look after refugees who are much closer to home than the Indo-Chinese refugees. The people who have suffered and are suffering by way of prison camps and torture closer to home, and in South America, have suffered 100 times what any refugee from Indo-China in recent years has suffered. A great many Indo- Chinese refugees who have come here by boat or in other ways can be seen only as economic refugees. Very few, if any, have suffered in concentration camps or from the vile torture that fascist governments are handing out in other parts of this world. I believe from a humanitarian point of view alone we should be looking at some of these countries where, as I said earlier, human rights do not exist and should be doing what we can to alleviate the suffering of some of those people.
