PROCTEXT.PARA: Assent to the following Bills reported:
Continental Shelf (Living Natural Resources) Amendment Bill 1981

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I deliver this statement on behalf of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) whom I represent in this place. Where I use the first person personal pronoun it should be understood to refer to Mr Viner. Wage determination and industrial relations are of the most profound importance to the welfare of all Australians and for the development of the Australian economy. Sound policies in these two connected areas are obviously critical to Australia's growth and prosperity as a nation. It is appropriate therefore that I place clearly before the Parliament the Government's policy regarding wage determination, industrial disputation and industrial relations legislation. I do so against a background of widespread community concern about the marked increase in industrial disputation which has taken place in recent times, against a background of very substantial increases in wages which have been received by much of the work force since the abandonment of wage indexation, and against a background of questioning of the traditional system, and of a desire by the community for action to ensure that a better way is found to resolve industrial matters.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's wages policy has been firmly established since the abandonment of wage indexation last July. It gives clear expression to the Government's basic philosophy and objectives and it is the product of a number of factors. The Commonwealth does not have direct power over wages. The Commonwealth cannot legislate for any particular wage level. As a result, the Commonwealth's role in wages determination is necessarily more indirect than with policy areas for which it has direct constitutional responsibility. At the same time, however, the Government has a major responsibility to make sure that the growth in wages does not frustrate the achievement of overall economic objectives. It remains the government's firm view that the sustained control and reduction of inflation is basic to the achievement of substantial economic growth and the improved living standards all Australians seek. Reasonable wage levels and competitive labour costs are obviously a key element in pursuing these economic and social objectives. The Government's wages policy needs to be seen in that context and in the light of the reasons why wage indexation had to be abandoned.

From its inception, the wage indexation could operate effectively only as long as the consensus between the parties necessary for its survival remained intact. This required the union movement to remain within the centralised wage fixing system and not to seek additional wage increases outside the system. Unless that condition was met, indexation could not survive. The work value round of 1979 was a clear indication that the system was beginning to falter. The Conciliation and Arbitration Commission warned of the threats posed by substantial wage increases outside the central system and the level of industrial disputation associated with the shorter hours campaign. But these warnings were not heeded. Disputation increases and pressures for wage increases outside as well as inside the indexation system continue to mount. The result was the abandonment of indexation in July 1981 and, as the Commission made clear at the time, the long- standing procedures whereby individual claims by unions would be heard by the Commission remained available.

The Commission also indicated that any application for adjustments on economic grounds would not be heard before February 1982. The Commonwealth Government moved quickly to consult national employers and unions as well as State governments to determine an appropriate course in the new circumstances. Following the Premiers Conference all governments called on unions to use the established system of wage determination involving Commonwealth and State tribunals. Moreover, they stressed that all governments and all parties involved had a responsibility to make the system work and that it would work if it were allowed to and if it were supported by all parties. Governments foresaw that wage claims would come before the Commission as they were pursued on an industry basis. That view was also endorsed by the Confederation of Australian Industry.

The main elements of the Commonwealth's wages policy in the post-indexation period have been: Maintenance of firmly anti-inflationary economic policies to establish an appropriate economic environment for wage restraint; reliance upon established arbitral tribunals and their processes; support for the more decentralised approach to wage settlements on an industry-by-industry basis; to emphasise that it is the responsibility of unions and employers to use the existing system in an orderly manner with a minimum of industrial disputation, and to be willing to give maximum commitment to agreements reached and to bring them before industrial tribunals for scrutiny in the public interest; a less direct role for the Commonwealth Government in interventions in individual cases reserving the Government's advocacy for national wage cases and major industry cases; and action in its own sphere of employment to ensure that wages and conditions do not lead the market. Consistent with the overall need for wage moderation the Commonwealth accepts that its employees' wages and conditions should be maintained in a reasonably competitive position.

In past months significant wage increases have been gained by a substantial proportion of the work force in both private and public sectors as the industry- by-industry approach has worked its way through industry bargaining and ratification by the Commission. On top of this there will be a national wage case later this month. The Government's response to this has to be viewed against Australia's present economic situation and prospects.
What Lies Ahead

The Government's policies over recent years have achieved considerable success in bringing about economic recovery. Let me remind the Senate that over the last two years living standards have risen and thousands of new jobs have been created-over a quarter of a million in the two years to December 1981. The facts are important to state at a time when the union movement and the Opposition would have the community believe the wage earner has suffered a loss of real value in earnings. This is patently not true. Seasonally adjusted average weekly earnings in September 1979 were $239.10 per week. By September 1981 they were $ 301.10 per week. In the same period the consumer price index increased by about 20 per cent. Thus in real terms average weekly earnings rose by about 4 3/4 per cent over the period. Putting it another way, the annual income of a person on average weekly earnings increased by over $700 in real terms.

Between fiscal year 1979-80 and 1980-81 real household disposable income rose by 3.42 per cent. That is, the real disposable income of Australian families- their after tax income-increased by nearly $3 billion. Movements in average weekly earnings in 1981-82 are expected to be broadly in line with the Budget forecase of 13.5 per cent. The full impact of recent wage and shorter house settlements will not, however, be felt until the 1982-83 financial year and may well be greater than for this financial year. The Government has emphasised to employers and unions alike the serious implications of excessive wage increases and industrial disruption for inflation, the competitive position of Australian industry and levels of unemployment.

All Australians should share the benefits of economic growth and the rising standard of living it brings, but there must be a recognition that there are limits to the growth of wages possible in any one year. Wage justice is compatible with moderation in wage settlements. Claims for wage increases have to be balanced against other calls on the resources of the community such as those for welfare beneficiaries and the need for investment funds by businesses. This view was supported by all governments at the August Premiers Conference. It is a view the Government has consistently expressed to the Australian Council of Trade Unions in economic discussions with its President, Mr Dolan, and senior union officials. It is a point of view which should be accepted and acted upon. The Government is firm in its commitment to ensure that its broad economic policies work to encourage a climate of wage restraint and to dampen inflationary expectations. Let there be no misunderstanding; the money supply will not be expanded so as to accommodate excessive wage increases. Economic policies will continue to be implemented to achieve this objective.

Conditions in overseas economies make restraint in Australia all the more important, for while our economy has been growing, and our national output and employment have been rising, our major trading partners have been experiencing continued recession, and growing unemployment; and as a consequence, inflationary presures in those countries have been falling. There is now a real prospect of inflation rates in Europe and North America dropping below Australia 's. This is a prospect which is compounded by excessive wage claims. Our international competitiveness, the profitability of Australian businesses and the confidence needed to maintain business investment are under threat. Job prospects both for those already with jobs and those looking for them, are correspondingly being reduced. Obviously the Government and the community want employers, unions and arbitral tribunals to act responsibly so that such an outcome is avoided. As the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development notes in its latest survey of Australia:

It is to be hoped that progress can be made in developing a better understanding between those who make and those who grant wage claims of the effects of their action, taking into account the relationships between inflation, real wage costs and employment.

The Government has been underlining to both employers and unions the broad national consequences of excessive wage increases for investment, economic activity and employment prospects for Australians. It is time then for the ACTU and its affiliate unions to take heed of the consequences of unrestrained wage demands and claims for shorter hours. Employers also have a very real responsibility to keep their work force fully informed of the impact excessive labour cost increases will have on investment, output and employment in their industry or enterprise. Against this background the forthcoming national wage case is of critical importance.

The ACTU is seeking substantial wage increases, possibly of the order of a further $25, for those wage and salary earners whose increases since the abandonment of indexation have been for lesser amounts. These increases would apply to a majority of the work force. On top of this the ACTU is seeking the introduction of full automatic quarterly cost of living adjustments commencing with the 4.2 per cent increase in the consumer price index for the December quarter. There is no way that the Australian economy can stand wage increases of this magnitude.

The Commonwealth's submission to the forthcoming national wage case will express our primary concern that existing wage pressures are not exacerbated by any national wage decision. The abandonment of indexation makes no less important the requirements of section 39 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act that the Commission shall take into consideration the public interest and for that purpose shall have regard to the state of the national economy and the likely effects of any awards with special reference to the level of employment and inflation.

With substantial industry wage settlements having moved through most of the work force and significant shorter hours agreements made in key segments of the economy, there is no room for any general wage increase to be granted in the national wage case and there should be no return to indexation. Such claims on top of wage increases obtained and being sought through industry by industry bargaining run the grave risk of doubling up on union wage demands, putting the health of the economy in jeopardy and causing the opposite of what the ACTU professes it wants to achieve for members of the work force-lowering instead of lifting their standard of living through accelerating inflation and reduced employment opportunities.

The Commission in the Transport Workers Union decision in July last, clearly indicated that the unions faced a choice as to how wage increases should be obtained: Either by way of general economic cases, that is national wage cases, or by way of increases at the industry and award level. They have chosen the latter course. The unions cannot have it both ways. The Commonwealth will submit most strongly that the industry by industry approach best meets the needs of the Australian economy. This approach best meets the needs of all, by offering a real chance of containing the rate of inflation while leaving open to all sectors of the work force the way to pursue their claims by negotiation or, if necessary, by arbitration where matters will be dealt with on their merits. The weaker unions will not be left out in the cold by this approach. It is wrong for the Opposition or the ACTU to say that they will be, for the State and Federal tribunals are always there for them to pursue their claims. The union movement itself has a heavy responsibility for the orderly processing of claims and ensuring that the industrially strong do not gain unfair or unreasonable advantage.

Apart from the national wage case, the Government will reserve its interventions before arbitral tribunals to major industry cases where agreements setting new standards for wages or other conditions of employment and having significant flow-on consequences are involved. This course was followed in the case of the metal trades agreement where the Commonwealth recognised the special features of that agreement-its 12 months 'no extra claims' clause and the willingness of the parties 'to run the gauntlet of the public interest'. Our submissions emphasised to the Commission the need to avoid flow-on of the agreement to other industries whose circumstances were fundamentally different.

In some other industries settlements which contain 'no extra claims' clauses have also come forward for scrutiny by industrial tribunals. This development offers the prospect of a reduction in industrial disputation during 1982 provided unions and employers accept their responsibilities to ensure that such agreements are honoured. It is some distance from a true 'no-strike' clause but I hope employers will in future bargaining put themselves in a position to push for such a clause. It is the ultimate test of the bona fides of the union movement. If the industry by industry approach is to be properly used the distinctive features of particular industries and the circumstances and terms of specific agreements reached by bargain and compromise must be recognised by employers, union and tribunals alike. Each claim has to be weighed and evaluated by the appropriate arbitral tribunal, having regard to the particular circumstances and the public interest.

The Government's decision to intervene to oppose ratification of the recent printing trades agreement on wages and hours is based on its concern for a settlement which is out of step with bargaining in other major industries. The agreement, by providing for a 35-hours week from December 1982, could lead to pressures for similar conditions in other industries when the economic situation requires the exercise of maximum restraint. The agreement to implement its terms regardless of whether it is ratified by the Commission brings into question the willingness of the parties to accept the obligation of justifying their agreement in the public interest before the Commission in order to render it legally binding on all parties to it.
Industrial Framework

It is not surprising against a background of a high level of industrial disruption that the institutional framework for industrial relations in Australia has been called into question. While arbitral tribunals have been ready to deal with wage claims, and have done so in a number of significant instances, the Government deplores the marked increase in the level of industrial disputation that occurred in the second part of last year. The figures I am about to quote are given in a way which corrects and clarifies the figures given by my colleague, the Minister for Industrial Relations, in his statement to the House of Representatives today. The latest official figures for industrial disputes show that in the September 1981 quarter 1,147,700 working days were lost through strikes compared with 848 600 working days in the September quarter 1980 and 631,000 working days in the December quarter 1980. All Australians have needlessly suffered as a result.

Of special concern were demarcation disputes and those in major industries caused by relatively small numbers of key employees. Demarcation disputes backed by unions placing bans on certain kinds of work or certain employers have become a blot on the industrial scene. The high point of such disruption has been the activity of the Builders Labourers Federation in Victoria.

The ACTU has adopted rules for self-regulation of inter-union rivalry but the glaring omission from its code is any requirement that industrial disruption cease while the dispute is sorted out. Unions cannot shrug off the consequences of their action upon industry and the community. The right given under the law to organise collectively is not a licence to ravage the trade and commerce of the nation with impunity. As a result of the concern of all governments about recent trends in wage movements and industrial disputation, especially those associated with demarcation issues, it has been agreed that these matters will be a major focus for discussion at the Premiers Conference to be held on Friday next.

Over the past few months I have engaged in extensive discussions with the major employer and trade union organisations in most States. In addition, representatives of many companies, both large and small, have discussed with me or written to me expressing their concern about such factors as:
The structure of Australian unions and their heavy dependence on craft unions rather than industry or even enterprise unions;
The breakdown in any sense of commitment to bargains made and the spirit and intent of the conciliation and arbitration processes;
The constant resort to the indiscriminate use of union power often before the parties have even reached the bargaining table: as an act of first rather than last resort;
The Federal-State division of industrial relations powers.

The development of a responsible approach by management and unions to industry wage bargaining is tied up with the shape of union structures and the rights and obligations placed by the law on each of the parties. It has become clear to me that many Australians-not only employers-are concerned at the lack of responsibility demonstrated by the trade union movement in its use of industrial action and the relative weakness of employers in the face of such action. It is now more than a decade since the Clarrie O'Shea case and the major industrial battle over absorption of the Metal Trades decision of 1967, during which time the union movement has declared itself against any legal restraints on industrial action and the untramelled right to strike and impose bans in almost any situation. I believe the Australian community is saying enough is enough; that no section of the community can be above the law.

Improving the institutional framework of industrial relations is a priority task. It is being approached in a number of ways. The implications of divided jurisdiction and ways of achieving better co-operation and consistency between Federal and State jurisdictions has been under review by Commonwealth and State Labour Ministers and will be canvassed at the forthcoming Premiers' Conference.

During this session I intend to introduce a number of legislative initiatives which I discussed with the National Labour Consultative Council on 4 February and which will be the subject of further discussion at a special meeting of that Council to be held in March. The Government has been accused of seeking confrontation with the union movement because of these legislative proposals. Far from being confrontationist, the three legislative proposals are a responsible and reasonable response, both immediate and longer term, to meet a level of industrial disruption which all Australians recognise as totally unsatisfactory. The Government has a clear obligation to develop legislation which will protect the interests of Australians and provide a sound and balanced legal framework within which employers and employees can conduct industrial relations.

The Government is very much aware of the problems associated with union structures which arise in part as a result of the large number of unions that operate in individual industries and range over particular enterprises. Much of the recent discussion about amalgamation of unions has failed to distinguish between the objective of allowing the creation of industry unions and amalgamations which create big conglomerate unions such as the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union, whose membership straddles a number of industries . Encouragement of the development of unions along those lines would not, in the Government's view, assist in reducing the level of industrial disputes to any marked degree.

The Government's long-standing objective, clearly expressed in its industrial relations platform, is the encouragement of industry based unions. It is also the objective of the Labor Party and the ACTU. Clearly that objective will take considerable time to achieve. The legislation I intent to introduce this session will facilitate the development of industry based unions and allow enterprise unions to be formed. The door needs to be opened to movement from within the workforce so that the present rigidities and monopolies are loosened and structures created which are more suited to a modern economy and representative negotiations in industrial relations and dispute settlement.

The multiplicity of the unions involved in individual industries also means that key workers who do not belong to the major union with coverage of a particular industry can create substantial industrial disruption and effectively deny useful employment opportunities to their fellow employees. Recent disputes in the waterfront and coal industries are prime examples of the major costs that such action causes. Increasingly rolling strikes and bans from plant to plant or industrial action by small key groups of workers have been used to put intense economic pressure on a single employer, a whole industry, or the community at large. In those circumstances quite often the employer has no work for the other employees. The employer's capacity to resist a strike is reduced to nothing because his wages bill goes on running. He needs protection in that situation and the Government intends to provide it. Consequently, I will be introducing legislation later this session to provide employers with the automatic right to stand-downs. Employees who are unable to be usefully employed because of the effects of industrial action by other employees of the same employer or industrial action by employees of other employers may be stood down.

It needs to be clearly understood that the stand-down clauses will operate only if there is industrial action. If unions accept the normal processes of negotiation and conciliation and arbitration instead of taking industrial action , stand-downs will not be required. The Commonwealth will be drawing on the Commonwealth's Constitutional power over interstate and overseas trade and commerce and over corporations as well as its industrial powers to support this legislation. The Government firmly believes in the right of the individual to choose to join or not to join a union. We do not believe in giving unions the capacity to exercise monopoly power over the working lives of people.

This Government has broadened legislation to allow individual employees to not become members of unions where they have a conscientious objection to doing so. Freedom of association on which unionism is based should not be distorted by denying the fundamental freedom of the individual.

We intend to go further and to legislate to incorporate the principle of voluntary unionism in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and to provide safeguards against intimidation or victimisation for those who exercise their freedom of choice in this matter. Moreover, I will introduce legislation withdrawing from the Arbitration Commission jurisdiction to grant union preference. This will greatly assist in reducing the incidence of the closed shop, which is a total negation of voluntary unionism.

These legislative initiatives are but the start of our program of reform. The Government, with the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Confederation of Australian Industry, is currently examining the report submitted by Mr Richard Searby Q.C. and former Deputy President Taylor on the simplification and streamlining of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. I expect that legislation action will be taken on the basis of that report later this year to bring about a substantial re-structuring and simplification of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. This should be of major benefit to all those associated with industrial relations in Australia. Ultimately reform of industrial relations in Australia needs to go further than simplifying and restructuring what we now have. I will be pursuing for the Government the work already begun against the bench-mark of what I regard as two basic principles-equality of bargaining power and the equality of legal responsibility of employers and unions.

The legislative initiatives I have outlined are essential if better industrial structures and industrial relations are to be achieved. Legislation of course sets the framework and establishes the rights, duties and obligations of the parties to industrial relations. In this sense the law can change or mould the conduct of people but fundamentally, of course, industrial relations is about relationships between people-employees and management. Unions, employers and governments have a common interest in avoiding industrial disputes, and providing for a fair and equitable wage determination system. The achievement of those objectives will facilitate the development of the Australian economy which is essential if improvements in our standard of living are to be achieved. The national interest is clearly being damaged by present rates of increase in labour costs so often pursued by severe industrial disruption. Union leadership, business management and individual wage and salary earners, need to recognise this and work to improve industrial relations and to contain the inflation in labour costs. Progress towards this unity of interest and purpose will be to the common and personal good of all Australians. I move:

For a taxpayer with a spouse and two children-the classic family-it has gone up from 12 per cent to 15.5 per cent. Taxpayers on average weekly earnings but not those on the higher incomes are now paying a greater proportion of their earnings in tax. —Not at his discretion. There has to be an industrial dispute.
—That is right.
—There is a big difference.

—But the point about it is that the right to stand down an employee is very much related to the common law right to suspend an employee which did not exist after the eighteenth century. What the English court in the eighteenth century said was: 'Sure you can sack somebody. You can employ him, you can sack him, but you cannot hang him up there in the air and say to him that he is suspended from work'. So they did not allow that. They did not allow that even in the eighteenth century.
—But the Commonwealth does that now.
—Your Commonwealth, Senator.
—Most effectively.

—Your Commonwealth does it, Senator, by getting a stand-down provision in an award or determination. This proposal is that the employer should have a right to do that without any reference to a stand-down provision in an award or an arbitral tribunal. That will lay the Government open to a lot of trouble. Even if, in one's wildest fantasies, one wanted to encourage a modern democracy in Australia, as the last sentence in the statement suggests, if one wanted to encourage good industrial morale and a feeling of belonging and participating in this society, which one would hope that honourable senators in their hearts would want to do, that is the wrong way to start. That, I suppose, is the most awful thing of all in this statement. Other things are just silly but that is bordering on the iniquitous.

SPEECH.PARA: The other thing which I find strange is that this Government will have an industry wage bargaining system and the capacity for enterprise unions. That does not seem to me to fit together very well. I hope that when we get the revised version of this statement-as it will have to be revised-that bit will be ironed out. I do not see how we can have enterprise unions and industry wage fixation. The two just do not seem to me to work together at all. If anybody could explain to me where I am wrong I would be grateful. I think the Government ought to have a look at that matter when it prepares its next version of the statement.

I should add that if the stand-down proposal survives this Parliament in my view it will not survive the High Court. There is no way in which one could say that the right to stand-down, in the circumstances suggested in this statement, is in any way related to or incidental to interstate or overseas trade, or commerce or corporation power. Of course, it is quite out of court under the industrial power of the Commonwealth which is to establish machinery of government for conciliation and arbitration for the settlement of disputes. This Government is saying that there will be no machinery. I think we ought to get rid of that here in the Senate to save costs in the High Court because it will go down the chute over there anyway.

There are a number of other rhetorical matters relating to altering the objects of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act which really only cast Mr Viner in the role of a radical. Mr Viner is a radical I do not know what, seeking in a radical sense to make quite dramatic changes to the history and development of industrial arbitration in this country. I am sure that the best developments of these kinds are ones which allow for a degree of continuity and adaptation of existing institutions to meet new circumstances. That sort of process is the one which will produce results, not this sort of root and branch change which I suppose Mr Viner got fixed in his mind after reading some book or-

TALK.START.PARA: —Comic Cuts.
—Or comics, or by visiting some other country, Picassoland or somewhere like that where he saw some system or other. What is the country where Papa Doc used to operate?
—Haiti.

—It might have been when he was visiting Haiti or somewhere like that or when he was examining industrial relations system in great detail on one of his overseas parliamentary study tours. He then came back here and rushed into this statement because of the desperate need to have something called a wages policy or because of the desperate embarrassment of the Organisation of Economic Co-operation and Development having in its report the Australian section which praises this Government-a bit written by the Treasury here. Perhaps there was some bug in the system in Paris who said: 'But we should also point out that they have no wages policy'. So that went into the report and all these embarrassments were heaped on the Government's head. There was a sudden recognition that this Government was not doing so well and so this statement was trotted out as a sort of a desperate effort to call spirits from the vasty deep before the Lowe by-election and the Victorian State election in April. It will not work in either of those two contexts and, of course, it will not work as a way of developing industrial relations in Australia. I invite honourable senators on the Government side to have a close look at what they are doing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Country Party in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take part in the discussion of the statement on wage determination and industrial relations. I suppose there could be no more important part of Australian society to discuss and to debate than just that. I want to make just one or two references to some of the things which were mentioned by Senator Button in his speech over the past 30 minutes or so. He started by suggesting that there had been something like nine major statements on industrial relations in the past six years or so of this Government. Indeed, he made that remark and the inference was that we had no capacity to solve any problems and that we were constantly changing our minds. I add to that observation the fact that there have been at the hands of all governments in this country more than 70 amendments to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act since it was founded some 70 years ago. The real inference that comes from both those statements surely must be that the industrial relations problem in this free society of ours has proved to be a very difficult problem to solve. A government, of whatever colour, would fail to live up to its responsibilities if it were not continually trying to come to grips with and in some real measure to solve this very problem. The evidence that has been put before us proves that it is a problem constantly in view and one which is difficult to solve. That certainly does not mean that we or anyone else should stand aside from it.

SPEECH.PARA: I was sorry that from time to time Senator Button moved away from his humorous jibes and, indeed, from his delightful capacity for a humouros approach. When he moved on to industrial relations he seemed to have no contribution at all to make except a measure of destruction. In fact, he said quite happily at one stage that his contribution to debates on industrial relations in this chamber over a significant period had been to say on every occasion: 'Well it won't work '-and he congratulated himself on being accurate. He said that was the view he took, and that was his contribution, and the inference was that that was a fine contribution. He merely said: 'It won't work'. We want something much better than that. I assume that if Senator Button and the Opposition in this chamber are not prepared to suggest in this place the real solutions to industrial relations problems, they do so in the electorate. I imagine that they tell the people of Australia how simple it is to solve these problems. Indeed, the Labor Party, having explained that to the Australian electorate over the past 33 years , has succeeded in convincing the Australian electorate that it had the answers to the problems for three of those years. For three years out of 33 apparently it provided answers to the community on these matters that convinced the community that the Labor Party should be the government.

Senator Button said that this wage determination and industrial relations statement was a diversionary action. Surely to come to grips with industrial relations matters in this country can hardly be said to be diversionary. It is certainly not an easy area and if one wanted to be diversionary one would move to an area where one could achieve more successfully and more easily something that may well appear to be a popular move in the community in which the Government and, indeed, the Opposition have a place and a policy to serve. Senator Button referred to average weekly earnings. As I recall, he said that as average weekly earnings went up the tax rate confronting people went up too. I think we should pause to consider tax rates in the Australian economy because it is so often being asserted that the rates are going up and people are paying more tax. Of course people are paying more tax. That is because they are earning a very great deal more money. The facts are that the rates of tax in this country now conform to three specific levels whereas previously they conformed to about seven specific levels. The position now is that if one earns in the vicinity of $18,000 a specific rate of 32 per cent will apply. Beyond $18,000 and up to nearly $36,000 of taxable income a rate of 46 per cent applies. Beyond that amount a rate of 60 per cent applies. There are then only three ratios or rates of taxation applicable whereas six years ago there were seven rates applicable. Constantly the more one earned the more likely one was to pay more tax proportionately than is the case in the current circumstance.

Whether we like it or not, many of the problems in this country are the problems of an affluent society. That does not mean that we should not recognise them or come to grips with them. Surely we must recognise their nature in that sense. Of the tens of thousands of young Australians and some older ones who travel, I suppose to the four corners of the globe every year, I believe that without exception all of them come back to their homeland in a matter of weeks or months or whatever of the opinion that this country we seem to berate so often and in so many places is indeed as good as or better than any other country to live in today. Let us keep it that way. Let us adopt a constructive attitude to the problems we can all recognise. Let us find some solutions that will retain for Australia and Australians the sort of attraction that Australia has had to this point. Indeed, I recall Senator Button making some references to the $20 a week pay increase that the Telecom employees achieved through whatever sources at the time when the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) was going to the royal wedding. I do not believe that that function had anything to do with the $ 20. It came from sources outside that particular area. If we are talking of $20 to solve a situation, I recall very clearly that only a week or two ago the Premier of my own State, Mr Wran, solved a problem with the coal miners by granting them a full $63 a week. That was his solution. Whether that has any relevance to economic stability and progress I am not sure, but I believe it is most unlikely that it has.

Senator Button also made considerable comment on the fact that some six years ago we undertook to maintain wage indexation and that on five occasions we had sought partial indexation and on 10 occasions we had sought no rise. I make no apology for that sort of action. I guess that it is a response to reality because the economic scene is always a changing scene. It is quite infantile to assume that one can apply a straight standard and maintain it year after year regardless, in many cases, of situations over which one will have no control at all. I am sure that in retrospect the Hon. Gough Whitlam would have the same reflections on his period in office. I seem to recall that during his time he sought not to put a government view or a view of restraint into the courts which were deciding areas for wages rates and standards in this country. He had no presence in those negotiations, discussions and debates and, of course, a fascinating escalation of wages was the outcome. That sort of escalation ended up with an inflation rate of somewhere in the vicinity of 17 1/2 per cent. So we can certainly see that it is responsible for a government to move into the courts that determine wages and conditions and a lot of other things referable to the economic community, to move in and take a realistic view of changing circumstances-in many cases, circumstances over which the Government and, indeed , the Australian people have little or no control.

When Senator Button was reflecting, as I recall, on the need that this statement on industrial relations suggests for a change in the structure of industrial relations procedures in this country with a view to attaining some form of realistic and constructive peace, he asked: 'Who questions the system?' I do not think anyone in this chamber or outside it would fail to question the system very seriously when around him he finds the sorts of industrial disasters that are occurring today and that have occurred for many months now. If that is not sufficient reason to question the system, I certainly do not know what is.

I do not mean to be highly critical of what Senator Button said because I must say that I believe his response to the statement was a good-humoured one. Whilst it did not succeed in pulling the statement to pieces, it certainly gave no really constructive alternatives. Senator Button referred to direct bargaining and, of course, there are arguments opposing that sort of thing. Yet when one examines the concept of direct industry to industry bargaining in the industrial relations legislation that will come down in the near future, one finds that it is not an irresponsible situation, because it will be direct bargaining in the presence of the employer and the employee and with the need for ratification by the Commission. Surely direct bargaining, if it does anything at all, must increase the pressure for responsibility on both the employer and the employee. If direct bargaining results in a situation that makes things economically impossible for the employer, there will be created a situation in which the employment and the economic trading capacity of the community are at stake. I do not believe that sensible organisations, at least those which do not seek to destroy the whole politically philosophical system of a free enterprise democracy, will have a bar of that sort of thing.

In this statement there has been foreshadowed the introduction of legislation which will make union amalgamations in all probability easier and result in the formation of industry unions. Industry-based unions are something that we have talked about over many years. They exist in a significant number of countries where the historical position differs very often from the Australian circumstance. I suppose that West Germany would be the truest indicator of an industry union situation. That country was able to start with a clean slate, as it were, after World War II. Industry unions have developed there and would appear to be successful. Amalgamations along those lines would bring, I believe, a greater responsibility to unionists and management alike. An industry union concept should bring a realisation of the interdependence of all people working right along the line throughout an industry, no matter whether they be plumbers, electricians, welders or whatever. They will be seen to be part of a total entity. The logical result of that would be that there would have to be a significant increase in the responsibility of each and every member of that particular union. I hope and believe that that sort of thing would prove to be acceptable in Australia and certainly to be worth the promotion and trial that this Government intends to give it.

Similarly, the legislation seeks to rub out the preference for unionism section in the principal legislation. I suggest that when people look at that proposition quietly and intelligently they will say: 'Why not? What is freedom all about? Is there a right to work? Is it necessary for one to be directed to a job or not because one is or is not a member of a union?'

TALK.START.PARA: —They accept the conditions that the unions negotiate for them .

—Yes, and they will continue to do that. The third area foreshadowed in this ministerial statement concerned stand-downs. Stand-down legislation has been held up by opponents of its introduction as something fairly horrific. The proposition is that a stand-down would apply only if there were industrial action, strike action, that made it economically impossible for another group of unionists in another related industry to be usefully employed. That seems to be a reasonable and responsible attitude. How can any economy survive if it is forced to pay wages or anything else in a situation in which it is totally uneconomic to continue?

SPEECH.PARA: I believe this statement on wage determination and industrial relations is of such significance that the whole Australian community should be paying an extreme measure of attention to it. It is necessary because it is relevant to the total development of the Australian economy. If it is relevant to that, it is relevant to the welfare of every Australian and to Australia's capacity to be a successful trader and a successful contributor to the nations around the world , developed and developing. There can be no doubt about the need for intelligent and serious discussion in this area. I believe that there is no more appropriate time than the present to bring these matters forward for the sort of discussion I have suggested. There is no more important appropriate time because surely in this country in recent months, particularly since the abandonment by the Arbitration Commission of indexation in July 1981, there has been practically no time when there has been a worse situation relating to industrial unrest. A whole spate of go-slow campaigns, bans and strikes really is starting to wear mighty thin the patience of even the great mass of Australians. So it is appropriate that the Government should bring forward this sort of discussion, this sort of promotion that contains within it some significant changes to the method and structure of industrial relations in this country.

There have been enormous wage increases since the abandonment of indexation. One can understand the sort of rush that followed that situation. Prior to the abandonment of indexation an attempt was made on the Government's behalf to institute a measure of restraint on wages, not for that reason alone but in order that inflation, which is probably the greatest single enemy of any Australian, could be contained. That sort of restriction was lost when indexation was abandoned and there was to be no consideration of a national wage case until February 1982-a week or two from now. In that period there has been an enormous rush for people to get as much as they can in the time available. That has been done totally and absolutely, I believe, without any reference to the sort of damage it could and may well do to the economy and the sort of jeopardy it may place around job opportunities in this country. It has been done without any reference to those matters at all. Indeed, we have seen, again in my own State, the problem of granting shorter working hours and very significant increases in wages without any reference in reality to productivity levels.

In the New South Wales power industry the 35-hour working week has been granted , allegedly on the basis of increased productivity, making it a proper, reasonable and responsible course to take. The facts are that in that period of six or seven months, the cost of power-there is mightly little of it-has increased by in the vicinity of 40 per cent. The community cannot stand that sort of thing. I believe that the community has a right to expect a government to examine a situation which allows that to happen and to try desperately to legislate for circumstances which will obviate those problems. They are the problems of every Australian. They are the problems of employment, inflation and capacity to trade. It is as basic as that. We are becoming perhaps non- competitive merely because we are not loading the ships, merely because we are failing to produce the power in a land that can do those things superbly.

I wish to talk for just a moment or two about the Government's wages policy. Since the abandonment of indexation in July of last year that policy has been firmly based on the direct negotiation between employer and employee and on the ratification of the resultant agreements and arrangements. Indeed, the situation has resolved itself into a rush, as I said a moment or two ago, to increase wage levels by as great a degree as is humanly possible, having total irrelevance to the capacity of the community to pay and to the public interest. A number of factors are referable to the wages policy of the Commonwealth. The first such factor-it is a very significant one-is that the Commonwealth has no direct power over wages and cannot legislate for any particular wage.

Having said that, I must insist that this Government and any government in this country has a very direct responsibility to make sure that the sorts of arrangements that are reached between employers and employees and looked at by the appropriate tribunals are arrangements that take real consideration of the public interest and of the capacity of the economy to pay. Indeed, if the capacity of the economy to pay and the public interest are not observed of course a depression across a very wide range of this community must be a certainty. We try to ensure that the growth in wage levels does not frustrate economic policy and performance. That is the province of a government, and that is the province that this Government seeks to follow in the course of its wages policy.

Sustained control and reduction of inflation must be the policy of the Government. That is more relevant to wage levels and the real affluence of a community than almost any other single thing. It is totally basic to economic growth and to living standards. (Quorum formed). I was talking about the need to ensure that all wage determinations have a relevance to the country's anti- inflationary situation and course and to the economic development of the whole community. It is worth remembering just why it was that wage indexation was finally abandoned by the Arbitration Commission. It was abandoned on grounds about which there had been constant warnings. They were that wage indexation was not going to work at any time if there was a constant effort towards and a constant fact of wage determinations and levels being arrived at outside the system. If we have a system of wage indexation and determinations constantly being made by people outside the system it will not work because it will create a great measure of discord. That is exactly what it did in this country which led to its abandonment in July 1981.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you think this legislation will do? Then there will be head-on confrontation. That is what you set out to achieve.

—That could be what Senator Keeffe wants but we are seeking to establish an industrial relations structure that will not bring confrontation but will give real opportunity for all individuals concerned, whether they be employers or employees, to express a strong point of view and to arrive at situations which will ensure-this is the important thing in any industrial relations proposition-the capacity of this economy to develop along the massive and fascinating lines it should be capable of doing.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth's wages policy in the post-indexation period-I mention these matters again; they were mentioned briefly in the statement itself-includes a determination to hold to an anti-inflationary course and to make wage restraint realistic. It is important and, I believe, absolutely reasonable to remember that wage restraint is realistic only if we can control inflation and keep it down. We have to rely on the established arbitral tribunals and their processes. That is part of this wages policy. We have, as I have already expressed, determined to support wage determination on an industry by industry basis. Naturally, it is the responsibility of unions and employers alike in that circumstance to abide by agreements and to subject them to the scrutiny of public interest. That is an important part of wages policy. I do not believe that many Australians would disagree with me. We should involve the Government in the advocacy of a national wage case and, perhaps, a few major industry cases . Finally, the Government's policy must be directed towards maintaining a relevance between wage structures and agreements and the capacity of the economy to pay. Its own employees, who must of necessity be properly and excellently remunerated, must not be seen to be the leaders in the field of wage determination.

I conclude my remarks by suggesting, once again, that this proposed legislation in the industrial relations area has a great deal to commend it. In many senses it sees a new era. It takes, as it always takes with any legislation, a real determination by both parties to wages agreements and by the tribunals themselves to see that justice is done in accordance with the public interest and the economic capacity of the Australian community. I suggest that this sort of legislative process will not harm the smaller, less powerful unions. They will always maintain their capacity for advocacy within the appropriate tribunals. Consequently, it is a red herring to assume that this sort of industry by industry negotiation will leave the smaller unions in a problem situation. That is not the case and I commend the statement to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard this evening much comment and criticism about the area of industrial relations. We have heard very few solutions to a vexing problem. I believe that the comments and criticisms have served more to confuse further the area than to clarify it. I will start my comments by referring to the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcom Fraser) at the beginning of the year that there was to be a new approach to industrial relations in this country. He said that we would try a period of conciliation and co-operation. That led many of us in industry to the hope that at least something positive was about to be done and that we would try to get some new initiatives in this area. It led me to hope that perhaps even industrial democracy may be given a brief chance of success. However, this new approach, as heralded by the Prime Minister, was very short lived. No more than a week later we heard that the Government proposed to introduce what can be described only as the most inflammatory approach to industrial relations that one could conceive. The Government said that it intended to introduce legislation for compulsory stand-downs. This legislation, apart from being inflammatory, was also unnecessary. Stand-downs, at present, are a matter between the unions, the industry and the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. We maintain that that is where the responsibility should remain. It is a complex question in a strike situation as to whether stand-downs should apply. It is impossible for legislation to try to bring in a situation that covers all possible contingencies. It can only inflame an already difficult area of industrial relations. The Australian Democrats give notice now that they will vigorously oppose any legislation that attempts to make it possible for automatic stand- downs.

SPEECH.PARA: If it is the Government's intention to use industrial relations as an election issue-that has been suggested-it is a very hypocritical approach. The Government has presided over the ending of indexation and, so far, has been unable or has refused to fill the gap in wage fixation. The Government's Pilate-like indifference has led to one of the greatest wage explosions we have had in this country. The inflation that this will cause and the problems it will create for those on fixed incomes will be very great. The unions are already moving to establish relativities following the recent agreement with metal workers. We can see only industrial chaos ahead. We believe that this chaos is brought about fundamentally because the Government has not been able to make up its mind whether to apply a centralised or decentralised wage fixing system. This basic conflict between the two approaches to wage fixation is at the core of our problems. There are, in fact, three approaches to wage fixation at present involving either a centralised approach or a decentralised approach.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are they do as you like to the third power?

—I will outline the three approaches. First of all there is the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission with its national wage case. Then there is industry-wide negotiation as we have seen in the recent negotiations with the metal trades and the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union. Both these approaches-wage fixing through the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and negotiation between an industry-wide union and an employer organisation representing a national industry-have resulted in the disastrous agreement between the Metal Trades Industry Association and the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union which is spearheading the present wages explosion.

SPEECH.PARA: The third approach to wage fixation is a decentralised approach. The first two I have just mentioned are centralised approaches. We can have a decentralised approach which involves negotiation between unions and companies. The problem in this country is that we are using all three approaches concurrently and this is leading to chaos. Companies are used to direct negotiation with unions. This happens every day of the week. Unions can knock on the door of any company and say: 'Here is a log of claims. We want to negotiate with you or we will pull employees in your factory out on strike'.

Senator Button claimed there was no experience of direct negotiation in Australia. The contrary is the case. Companies are negotiating directly with industries on over award payments all the time. The problem is that unions want the best of all worlds. They want a centralised wage fixing system, they want to retain the ability to hear cases in the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, they want to retain the ability to negotiate with employer bodies such as MTIA and they are also insisting on their right to negotiate directly with companies.

Centralised wage fixing can work given two pre-conditions. One is that the unions are prepared to forego their right to direct negotiation and abide by the decisions of the Commission. In the absence of this undertaking, it is difficult to see how a centralised wage fixing system can work satisfactorily. We also have the additional problem in this country of overlapping State and Commonwealth legislation on industrial matters. This brings the Australian Democrats to the conclusion that inevitably we are progressing towards a decentralised wage fixing system, one of direct negotiation and direct bargaining. Essentially it is our solution to the problem as we see it in this country. Because the parties concerned have shown an unwillingness to make a centralised wage fixing system work, we are advocating that we adopt the alternative which is a decentralised system based on direct negotiation between the company and the union.

I believe there has been confusion in the discussion so far because the words ' company negotiation and company unions' and 'industry negotiation and industry unions' have been used rather loosely. I understand the terms 'industry unions and industry negotiations', to mean a national industry such as the metal industry or the transport industry. When we talk about a company union we are talking about a union that relates to a specific company. We make the point that industry wide negotiations must still be regarded as a centralised approach to wage fixing and this is essentially the system that is causing the problem in Australia at the moment.

The statement also goes on to indicate that the Government proposes to encourage industry unions. The Democrats support this approach. We believe it is consistent with our suggestion that we move to direct negotiation, a direct bargaining approach to wage fixing, the decentralised approach. We can have industry wide unions and we can have branches of those unions that are applicable to specific companies. Generally speaking this is the situation that applies in the United States of America and it works well. It would gradually lead to overcoming the basic problem of a great multitude of unions operating within an individual company.

The other point that the statement raises is the question of compulsory unionism. It has been indicated that there should be legislation to eliminate preference in employment to union members. It is our view that unions are well able to look after their own affairs. On principle we are opposed to any legislation in existence at the moment that encourages compulsory unionism.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you do about the company based union when it has four employees? Who looks after them? Do you revert to the Victorian era and the employer does all that, does he?

—No. Where there is a small number of employees in a company they can belong to the industry based union. Small companies could combine if they wished to negotiate as a consortium with the industry based union. That would be quite consistent with direct bargaining.
—Is the large enterprise union separate from that?

—Frankly, I am not sure what is meant by a large enterprise union. This is where I have been confused. As far as I can see there are two terms, an industry union and a company union. I am not too sure where an enterprise union comes into it, unless the words 'enterprise' and 'industry' are synonymous or 'enterprise' and 'company' are synonymous. It must be one of those two alternatives. I am making the point that we are in favour of industry wide unions that have branches within the company. That is not substantially different from the situation that applies right now in many cases in the metal trades. The AMWSU is as close as it could possibly be to an industry wide union in relation to the metal industry. It is a national union and right now it negotiates on a company by company basis on over award payments. The significant difference that we advocate is this: In decentralised negotiations, in direct bargaining, it is essential that the negotiation result in a written agreement that can be legally binding. Unless that is done we have really achieved nothing . The unions should not be in a position where they can negotiate, come to an agreement and walk away without undertaking that they will not be back next week or next month.

SPEECH.PARA: In summary we are saying that a decision must be made between the two approaches to wage fixation, either centralised or decentralised. The unions must be prepared to say that they are moving in one direction or the other. They cannot continue to advocate that they want the best of all worlds. It is intolerable for unions to have direct negotiations resulting in an agreement and then the following week, the Commission having brought down a national wage increase-
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

Many honourable senators will be aware that during the recess Mr Tom McIntosh, a long serving member of the Senate staff, passed away. Tom McIntosh joined the Senate as an attendant in February 1970 and later in the year became the Assistant Transport Officer, a position he held until December 1973. From January 1974 he served in the Records Office and remained there holding a variety of positions until his untimely death on 15 January 1982. Tom also served the Senate and the Parliament when he worked in the Government Printing Office for a number of years prior to joining the Senate. Over those many years Tom McIntosh served the Senate well.

I know that he was held in the highest regard by many honourable senators, not only for his devotion to his work, but for his particular expertise in the area of tabled papers and the Parliamentary Papers Series, an area in which he was widely renowned as the parliamentary expert. He endeared himself to his many friends in the Senate and other areas of Parliament House by his straight forward approach, good humour and his willingness to help. Such qualities in these days are all too rare.

Tom is survived by his wife Cynthia and his five daughters. It would be remiss of me not to say that this man was a very devoted husband and father. It is a side of Tom McIntosh which I believe is not well known by honourable senators but is one which is respected and admired by his many close friends. Tom McIntosh will be sadly missed by this chamber and those who had the privilege to work with him in this building. I again express to Mrs McIntosh and her family my deepest and sincere sympathy on Tom McIntosh's death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr President, personally, and on behalf of Government senators, I join with you in extending sympathy to Mrs Cynthia McIntosh and Tom McIntosh's five daughters. Like youself, Sir, and like so many of us who have been here for quite a while, we knew and, I think it is not too extravagant to say, were fond of Tom McIntosh. He was a man who gave affection and therefore he attracted our affection. Therefore, it is doubly sad. So often this Parliament is depicted to the people outside by those of us who are in the front line and those who make the noise day by day. However there are people like Tom who give to the Parliament and to the parliamentary institution a type of service that is essential to the running of the parliamentary system. I want his family to know that, in his untimely death, we too have lost a very valued friend and the Parliament has lost a very fine and dedicated officer. His death, of course, was , as I have said, quite untimely and sad for us all.

SPEECH.PARA: Like most honourable senators who came into the Senate about the time that I did, I first came across Tom McIntosh when he held the position of Assistant Transport Officer. Most of us, I think, will remember him for that and for the tremendous service that he gave us so cheerfully. Somehow or other with that intuition that only transport officers have, he knew how the Senate was going to run, what time and how it would finish and where we were all going, and ahead of us all he was able to offer that kind of service. There is not one of us here who will not remember him with deep gratitude and affection for that. He will be remembered by us for the cheerfulness he always showed to us at Parliament House or at Canberra Airport when greeting or farewelling us.

After he went to the Records Office I did not have as much contact with him although occasionally I did. However, I am well aware that he served there very well indeed. He was a man who, as you have said, Mr President, was very devoted to his family and his death will be a great personal loss to them. In expressing sympathy to his family, I hope that the knowledge that there are many of us who are trying to share their sense of grief may help them to carry the burden a little. The gentleness that time does have will soften the blow for them, but we will nevertheless retain in enduring fashion the memory of a man whom we were proud to walk alongside and call a friend.

SPEECH.PARA: From time to time in a world when death and oppression are far too common, when the abuse of civil liberties and freedom is also very common, an event occurs which concentrates our attention on the injustices and abuses which occur in particular regions of the world. Such an occasion, I believe, was the death on 5 February, this month, in a cell at the security police headquarters in Johannesburg, South Africa, of Dr Neil Aggett, the Transvaal Secretary of the African Food and Canning Workers Union. At various times the Senate has discussed such examples of collective oppression as the invasion of Afghanistan and East Timor, the present events in Poland, the abuses by the Pol Pot regime in Kampuchea and the Pinochet regime in Chile, the suppression of civil rights in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, in El Salvador and individual cases like the death of Steve Biko in South Africa and the farcical trial of Kim Dae Jung in South Korea.

It is appropriate, I believe, that some reference should be made to the life and death of Dr Aggett. Neil Aggett was 28 years old when he died. He trained as a medical practitioner. He gave up medicine to become an official and later Transvaal Secretary of the African Food and Canning Workers Union, a union of mixed races but predominantly a black union and one of South Africa's oldest free trade unions. He was one of those courageous white South Africans willing to work in a hostile environment for the principles of free trade unionism and against the oppression of the black majority in that country.

On Friday 5 February he died, apparently by hanging, in his cell where he was in solitary confinement. He had been detained in November last along with other trade union officials, students and church leaders in a round up of what the South African Government authorities considered to be subversives. At first he was detained under the General Law Amendment Act in South Africa which authorises detention without trial for 14 days and then, as is the usual practice in that country, he was detained under the Terrorism Act which allows indefinite detention. He had not been charged. No trial date was notified. He was allowed no visitors. Neither his parents nor any of the parents of the others who were detained at the same time with him could find out anything about the reasons for his detention. His best friend, also a doctor, who was also detained was not permitted to attend the funeral.

His was the forty-sixth death in detention in police custody in South Africa since 1963. He was the first white person to die in custody in this way. The authorities' initial claim was that he committed suicide. His friends and his medical colleagues either doubt or do not believe this story-not an unreasonable attitude in view of the history of deception and outright lies in previous cases by the security police in South Africa, in particular, in the more recent case of Steve Biko, the one which has recently received the most publicity.

The members of the ruling group in South Africa-of course white, predominantly Afrikaans-claim to be devout Christians. They use their religion to justify the suppression of the majority and their racial theories of apartheid. They claim that the country is a democracy yet they deny the majority the vote or any share in power. They claim a system based on the rule of law but they allow detention and arrest without charge or trial. They permit the cover up of abuses of civil rights and even death as demonstrated in the Biko case. Like all authoritarian regimes they refuse to allow the operation of free trade unions. It is in this atmosphere that Neil Aggett became a trade union official rather than enjoy the benefits of medical practice in that country. He advocated openly for the disenfrachised and the oppressed in the country, for the freedom to vote and to join in free association in trade unions which we in this country take for granted. I believe it is to our disgrace that so many in this place defend and support the regime which exists in South Africa and claim that it represents a bastion of freedom on the African continent and in the world.

It is ironical that Neil Aggett was, in fact, a doctor. His profession in South Africa emerged from the investigations into Steve Biko's death with a tarnished reputation. The doctors have accepted that they can be overruled by the security police when treating patients. The South African Medical Association will not take responsibility for what happened or make any meaningful investigation into what happened, hiding behind legalistic barriers rather than asserting its moral responsibility in this matter. The medical faculty at Dr Aggett's own university , Witwatersrand, has asserted that the Biko affair resulted in a cover up. The profession as a whole has collectively washed its hands of this disgraceful affair. Its members are in disgrace. One wonders what they, in fact, will do now that one of their own colleagues has suffered from this system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Surely the medical examiners let the whole country down, didn't they?

—The medical examiners let the country down. The medical examiners refused to testify in the investigations. The South African Medical Association accepted the fact that the medical profession in that country in dealing with people in custody is secondary to the security police. I think it is a shame quite frankly, Senator Baume, that the organisation that you belong to and that I used to belong to has not taken a greater stand on this matter than it has.

SPEECH.PARA: Dr Aggett was allegedly found hanged in his cell. His death was quite clearly either murder or suicide and his friends, as I have said, believe it was murder. Whatever the cause, he is quite clearly the victim of a system which is designed to crush ruthlessly all opposition in the name, ironically, of democracy and Christianity. If he indeed committed suicide what sort of a system is it which drives a young man, well educated, in good health, motivated by high ideals, to take his own life after three months detention? I quote the lawyers for human rights in South Africa, who stated:

Even if it is found that Dr Aggett took his own life as claimed the question remains: what makes death preferable to detention? Detention without trial and in solitary confinement is a cruel and inhuman punishment. No effective safeguards can or will be found to prevent its abuse.

This man was placed in solitary confinement for activities conducted openly and considered normal in any free country. If he was murdered we will probably never know. If it, in fact, was suicide it is a disgrace in any community considered to be civilised that he should have reached such a desperate state and, I suppose one can say, particularly in such a short time. His death, of course, has resulted in widespread criticism inside and outside South Africa. The Federation of South African Trade Unions and the Trade Union Council of South Africa have protested and, almost unprecedented in South Africa, wide strikes resulted from his death. At his funeral, the Cathedral, the streets and the cemetery were packed with people and the emotional scenes, the desperation, the frustration and the defiance of those present, as could be seen in the brief television screenings that we saw here, demonstrated quite obviously the feelings of those present. Some good may come of his death. The other detainees who were picked up at the same time as he was were, for the first time after his death, allowed visits from their parents and other relatives. The trade union movement in South Africa was temporarily united. Unfortunately though the courageous Press in South Africa, limited in its operations, will be further restricted by legislation pending in the South African Parliament.

We may not get full reports of just what has happened in this case and even in subsequent cases. It is to be hoped that those courageous South African citizens , black, coloured or white who are willing to take on the oppressors in the Nationalist Party, the Broederband, the security police and other organisations in that country will not be disheartened by what has happened, but, in fact, inspired and assisted. It is to be hoped that those apologists for this regime in this country will rethink their position. Dr Neil Aggett was a brave, dedicated idealistic man willing to live up to his beliefs in a way that few of us, I might suggest, are willing to do. He is a reminder to us all that it is due to such people that freedom survives throughout the world. That the Australian Government chose to make no statement about the matter is disappointing. One can quote from many articles and editorials written in this country and other countries after his death. I will quote from only one, the Melbourne Herald of 15 February, a paper I suppose that is not often quoted from my side of the Parliament. It states in part:

Dr Aggett's death and the funeral demonstration speak of both hope and hopelessness. Hope can be seen in the way that he, and many other whites, have defied evil at personal risk. Little hope can be found, on the other hand, that the rigidity at the heart of the white controllers of the nation is softening. A crackdown on the remaining freedoms of the English-language media is in the air. South Africa is defiant on Namibia, agressive in Angola. Can no international action really confront the arrogant Afrikaners?

I raise this matter merely because I think it is important that an incident like this, which has aroused such international interest and has drawn, once again, our attention to the oppressive situation in South Africa should be on the records of this Parliament. I hope the fact that it is on the records and the fact that it has happened will make those who I mentioned before who are repeated apologists of what happens in South Africa think again and re-look at the situation so that this country at least can be united against the sort of oppression which occurs there.
