TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a matter related to the subject of assisted migration from the United Kingdom to Australia. I understand that no money is available at present to bring out those migrants who have been selected under the assisted migrant program. The fact that money is not available has raised a number of problems. I want to make a suggestion which might assist to overcome some of the problems which have been raised in this area. I would like to illustrate with the case of a boilermaker-welder from Jersey in the Channel Islands. This gentleman is a married man with two children who has relatives in Australia and who was selected last year to come to Australia. I will read extracts from a letter from the Australian High Commission in London to him. The letter reads:

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to inform you that your application for an assisted passage to Australia has been approved. This is on the basis of your going to the State of New South Wales.

As you are aware, the Australian Government has already announced the cessation of the Assisted Passages Scheme. However, approved applicants may receive the benefit of assisted passage provided they travel before 30th June 1982. In view of this decision I would encourage you to commence finalising your affairs so that you will be able to depart promptly once you have been notified of a firm travel date.
This letter was sent from the United Kingdom to Australia. On the back of the letter the wife of the gentleman concerned wrote to her relatives in the following way:
We phoned movements section-
Movements section being part of the Australian High Commission Office-
because we couldn't finalise any plans as our accommodation was tied with George 's job-they then told us by phone to give notice and return to U.K. to be ready for our firm date.

On the basis of this written and oral advice the gentleman concerned gave up his job, spent Christmas with his family in Clydeside and converted his assets, furniture and so on, into cash ready to come to Australia. He was then advised that no money was available but that it might be available some time in 1983. We have a situation where the gentleman finds himself with no job and no prospect of employment. Clydebank, where he was living at the time, has one of the highest unemployment rates in Britain. No accommodation was available to him because, of course, the accommodation that he had was associated with his previous job and he has relinquished that job. His relatives, with whom he was living over the Christmas period, were not able to accommodate him, his wife and two children because of a scarcity of accommodation. He then found that the small amount of capital that he had built up to come to Australia through the sale of his effects and what he had accumulated in his work time was being dissipated supplementing his dole payments. So he decided to pay his own fare and come to Australia. The problem is that he will not be reimbursed. The money which should have been made available now will not be paid to him. So he has spent his savings and his accumulated capital coming to Australia.

At this stage I will not make any comment about the situation where people are selected, told to give up their job and then dumped. A government which does this sort of thing needs to look to its own conscience. I simply ask that the money which he has paid out should be reimbursed to him when money is available. It is quite clear that we must have wanted him to come in the first place because we selected him. We were prepared to make money available to assist him to come to Australia. So the problem which he faces at present was created by government bungling and mismanagement. We made a commitment to this family both in writing and verbally, and we should keep that commitment.

I reject the argument that if he has the money he ought to pay his own fare. It is quite clear that the man did not have sufficient money to come originally; otherwise he would not have been granted an assisted passage. He made up the money with which he was able to pay his fare by selling off those assets which he had accumulated in the way of furniture for his house and savings that he had . This money would have been needed to set himself up in Australia and to replace those things which he sold in the United Kingdom to come to Australia. Of course, if the money were to be spent it would be spent in Australia and would not go outside. But that is not the point. I think it is a matter of principle and fair play.

I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to consider agreeing to a refund in this case and the other few cases where assisted migration has been promised. We created this problem-'we' being the people of Australia. Let us keep our credibility as a nation. We should not make a commitment, involve people in changes to their lifestyle, promise them things and then leave them in the lurch. I request the Minister to refer this recommendation to the responsible Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that, with Canada and the USA, we have more than met our obligations under our refugee program. I know that there are tremendous pressures. I know that in any country's immigration policy, particularly our own , it is one component that has to be evaluated against the others, including the normal family reunion and job category components. But I do echo the sentiments of Senator Primmer. I believe that on a numerical basis our intake from Latin America has been relatively small. In the light of what is contended by our Uruguayan colleagues, I appeal for a response in the near future from our appropriate representatives in Brazil or one of the adjacent embassies on why we have been so slow in this respect.

SPEECH.PARA: I concede that the United States experienced difficulties. I know also from the days of Foreign Minister Willesee that sometimes some governments are inclined to produce people who do not meet the refugee criteria. They can be, to say the least, odd people. But I know enough about the Uruguayan community in Sydney to make this appeal. It is buttressed by Senator Primmer's experience in Victoria. They are putting up a case for our meeting the request of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees concerning Uruguay. It is not the only country with which some of us have had difficulties. Bolivia is another. I suppose it is a case of the harvest being great and the labours few. Even there, with the aid of a number of unions in Sydney, we were successful with some neo-refugee problems when it took quite a while to get out families of trade unions and university activists.

I make that appeal as an external obligation. I say that deliberately because I have had further overtures from the Uruguayan community in Sydney, which expressed quite a reasonable complaint that, when many of them go back to their homeland or place of birth, if you like, to visit relatives and they have with them children who were born out here and have Australian passports, Uruguayan officials are not above sneering and talking about 'your foreigner children'. At this time of night I am not going to get into the matter of dual nationality. I think it is fitting that Senator Gareth Evans is in the chamber when I am speaking about this matter because last year he sounded the tocsin and asked why we do not chastise more vigorously Latin American ambassadors here when there are proven examples of torture and of a complete cessation of civil liberties. I simply say tonight that we could do no worse than ask our Department of Foreign Affairs or, if necessary, the Minister himself, the Honourable Anthony Street, to ask the Uruguayan Ambassador to Australia whether people born here of Uruguayan parents are going back to Uruguay and being subjected to sneers and jibes. I know that if that were to happen in countries in Eastern Europe there would be a lot of protest. I accept that there should be such protest. But I like to be even-handed and I would like that aspect to be investigated.

I conclude on a more serious note. This communication that I have contained the assertion that a Mr Lemos, who was a member of repressive forces in Uruguay, came to Australia in 1971 and is working as a security officer at the Kelloggs Cornflakes plant in Botany in New South Wales. Again, the complaint is made by these people of Uruguayan origin in Australia that when they do visit their homeland there seems to be a sort of unhealthy interest in or knowledge, if one likes, of whether they have been to El Salvadorian, Nigerian or Chilean functions, countries which are not very favourably disposed, and rightly so, towards these military dictatorships. There is a sort of civilian ring. They claim that a Mr Lemos, who is security officer at the Kelloggs Cornflakes factory in Botany, New South Wales, apparently has plenty of time to carry out surveillance of these people as a form of intimidation. As honourable senators know, I am one of those who believe in the retention of a federal law enforcement agency. I accept the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation if it has an even-handed policy. On the question of our intake of political refugees, this may be a matter for the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee), but I would also like to believe that the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) will confer with the current chief of ASIO and find out about Mr Lemos. I have discussed this matter with a number of Latin-American members of the Mill Employees Union-I hasten to add that Mr Lemos is not a member of that union but a security officer at Kelloggs-and while one of the officials I spoke to, who was a fairly broad-minded man, did not say outright that Mr Lemos may be involved in spying on people of Uruguayan origin, he did say: 'Well, he is certainly an arrogant man'.

In review of the assertions made by members of the Uruguan community, I do not want to see another Srecko Rover incident. We all know that he was a Pavelic supporter. He still resides in Victoria. The Townley Committee was a very powerful committee. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no wish to detain the Senate for more than a few minutes at this very late hour but I do wish to put on the record some additional information about a matter which has attracted a fairly lively degree of attention in the last few days and which does also raise a couple of important matters of principle. Last Friday, from around 11.30 p.m. until the early hours of Saturday morning, a major series of raids was conducted on 53 Melbourne massage parlours by a task force comprising some 120 members of the Australian Federal Police, the Victoria Police and officials of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, all acting under the direction of the Australian Federal Police.

SPEECH.PARA: The centrepiece of that raid and the part of it which attracted the media attention of which I have been and will again be critical tonight involved a group of approximately 30 massage parlours in a single block off St Kilda Road which was cordoned off for this purpose. The object of the police raid involved an attempt to break what on any view sounds like a rather nasty immigration vice racket, allegedly involving South American and Asian women illegally entering the country and being employed at sub-standard wages-if that is the appropriate terminology for this industry-for their activities. In the result some six people were arrested and charged. Some 27 people had been held on suspicion or held for questioning early on, to employ the favoured police euphemism in this respect, but only six people in the event were charged.

So far perhaps so good. Prostitution is a sordid business at the best of times particularly when it is linked, as it so often is, with drug taking and, as was apparently potentially the case here, with organised crime. It is no less sordid when it is conducted in the glittering environment of Melbourne's massage parlour row. Certainly there can be no objection, and I make no objection, to a police raid with the objective I have mentioned carried out efficiently, expeditiously, fairly and with no unnecessary drama. But that is not what happened last Friday night. What we had instead of a raid conducted in those circumstances is something that is perhaps better described as a tasteless media orgy laid out in all its splendour not only in some Saturday newspaper reports but more particularly on Saturday night television in the reports of most channels, I think, certainly including the Australian Broadcasting Commission. The television coverage to which I refer took the form essentially of quite extensive film of those emerging from the parlours in question as the police entered the premises one by one and having to run the gauntlet of police and television camera floodlights with a rapidly growing crowd of jeering onlookers, no doubt attracted by the flurry of activity in St Kilda Road.

TALK.START.PARA: —A grand final atmosphere.

—Indeed, it was. One might put it that way. The operation, which was rather aptly codenamed Butcher, was carried out, I suggest, with a quite spectacular disregard for the dignity and privacy of those caught, sometimes literally, with their pants down in these circumstances. I acknowledge that the initial disposition of many of those who perhaps witnessed this television coverage may well have been to chortle at the acute and obvious discomfort of the people involved in the television coverage in this way. But I also suggest that the reaction of anyone with any sensitivity at all after that perhaps initial reaction would have been one of fairly profound distaste for the nature of the media coverage which was thus being generated. A number of the faces and figures on the screen would have been undoubtedly quite recognisable to those who knew them and perhaps had no knowledge of the nature of the profession or business in which they were involved or, in the case of the clients in question who happened to be caught up in this of the nature of their behaviour on that particular night. There is, of course, a potential for profound embarrassment not only for the individuals themselves but also, in some cases, for quite innocent members of the family-children at school and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: Most of those caught up in this particular extravaganza clearly were committing no crime-certainly not one for which they were being pursued or with which they were in fact charged on the night in question. I believe it is quite indefensible to expose those individuals, whatever one thinks of their moral behaviour, to contempt and ridicule of this kind. I make that point quite seriously. I do so also in the context, as far as the media is concerned, of the continuing, indeed growing, debate that is emerging in the community as to the desirability or otherwise of privacy protective legislation being passed by parliaments around the nation. We are constantly being told that such legislation is not only potentially dangerous as an intrusion on media freedom but also unnecessary because the media can be relied upon to exercise a degree of self-regulation and self-restraint in these sorts of circumstances. I fear that the media coverage, particularly the television coverage, of Friday night's affair was a spectacular counter-example. So much for the role of the media.

Might I have also a word or two about the role of the police in this matter, which does appear to leave something to be desired. What I suggest is that this lapse of media taste-if it might be so described-was made worse by the fact that it was, on my reliable information, deliberately set up and orchestrated by the Australian Federal Police through its director of information, Mr Gregson Edwards. It appears that early on the Friday night Mr Edwards arranged for all radio stations, television stations and newspapers in question to be informed of the impending raid through Australian Associated Press telex. Radio and television crews were singled out for specific invitation and a rendezvous outside the St Kilda Road barracks was, in fact, specified. Reporters and camera crews were asked to await the arrival of Mr Edwards personally who would appear in a car numbered ZUD 218 at around 11.30 p.m.

I am told reliably that Mr Edwards duly arrived at the appointed time, handed out background briefing sheets, directed the television and other crews to the scene of the action and ferried at least one reporter around from vantage point to vantage point. What could have been and undoubtedly would have been, without the manipulation of the impresario Mr Edwards, a perfectly efficient and expeditious as well as justifiable police exercise, was converted-it seems to me as a result of that intervention and orchestration-into something that can be described only as a raunchy circus.

It is time that our police forces appreciated that respect for them and their work depends upon the quiet, efficient and fair performance of their proper functions and not the manipulation of privacy-invading extravaganzas that I believe would be out of place even on most American television crime shows. If the police want to claim, as they do, that respect for civil liberties is part of their way of operational life-thus making legislation like the impending Criminal Investigation Bill unnecessary-I suggest that they will have to demonstrate in the future a lot more sensitivity than was shown on this occasion .

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Evans raised a matter which I heard him raise first on a morning radio program a couple of days ago. The Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) is aware of the matter and he has already expressed his concern about the incident. He has also called for a full report on the matter and he may be in a position at a later time to confirm, deny or amend some of the details which have come out. I would agree with Senator Evans that it is not a question of whether it is desirable to stop the practices, but the process of the law and the role of the media are matters of concern. I understand that Senator Evans has a particular concern about the action of the Director of Police Information. He has raised that concern tonight. For my part I am at a loss to know why radio and television cover is even desirable when this kind of raid or activity takes place. This matter will be referred to the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman). I know that he is interested in it. I am authorised to say that he has expressed his concern and he is looking into the matter now. I say this not in any critical way, but had I had some notice I might have been able to get more information.

Senator Grimes raised a matter concerning the death of Dr Neil Aggett. I am reminded when I talk to my own rabbi that he has a fairly marked South African accent. Sometimes we ask him: 'Why did you leave South Africa?'. His reason is that the final straw came when the security police visited him the day after he delivered one of his Yom Kippur sermons. He thought that if giving a sermon was going to mean a visit from the security police it was time to leave the country. Let me say that he has been a gain to Australia. We have had a number of gains from South Africa, a number of refugees. I am reminded of Irving Frankel, a jurist who appeared for some of the people interned by the South African Government and who is now practising law in this country with distinction.

The issues of summary arrests, solitary confinement and unexplained and unnatural death are matters which concern us all, as do the other questions Senator Grimes has raised about the proper role of citizens and, in the case he raised, the role of medical professions in making known their concerns and not being party to certain practices. I am as concerned about the events in South Africa as I think most honourable senators would be. I am also concerned about the events in a whole range of countries of left or right persuasion where these kinds of things are happening. I am concerned about some of the events in Poland . I am concerned about Kampuchea and Chile. I am concerned about the Gulag Archipelago. I believe that Solzhenitsyn was telling the truth. I am concerned about Iran. I am concerned about Idi Amin's Uganda. I am concerned about the matters raised by Senator Mulvihill a little while ago. It does not seem to matter which country it is; it does not really help for people on one or the other side of politics-I am not suggesting that Senator Grimes did this; my remark would apply to anyone-to pick one example. All examples are thoroughly reprehensible. I would like to think that we would pursue in this country our interests in all the people who are improperly arrested. Those who have read the books of Nadine Gordimer will know in a very vivid way some of the things that are going on in South Africa and some of the concerns they give to many people.

The Parliament of Australia has an Amnesty group. Many honourable senators and members from all sides and members of the staff of the Parliament belong to the Amnesty group and are active in it. I had the honour to be on an Amnesty mission to Indonesia a few years ago together with a leading lawyer and the Chairman of the Council of Churches. What is important about the Amnesty group in the Parliament is that it is quite impartial in relation to the people it tries to sponsor and tries to look after. If we can learn anything from the unfortunate events of recent days and the death of Neil Aggett it is just to have emphasised once again the desperate situation of many people in many countries and, perhaps , to understand the fragility of the freedoms we enjoy in Australia. I will make known Senator Grimes's concern to my ministerial colleagues in case there is anything that they want to add.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
